B) Amphotericin and 5-flucytosine
C) Ceftriaxone
D) Ceftriaxone and vancomycin
E) IV fluids and monitoring
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>32-year-old man</fact1> presents to the emergency department with <fact2>fever, nausea, and vomiting</fact2>. The patient states that his symptoms started <fact3>last night</fact3> and have persisted to this morning. He has a past medical history of <fact4>asthma</fact4>, and his current medications include <fact5>albuterol and fluticasone</fact5>. His <fact6>temperature is 102°F (38.9°C)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 95/min</fact8>, <fact9>respirations are 17/min</fact9>, and <fact10>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact10>. On physical exam, the patient seems uncomfortable. He requests that the <fact11>lights in the room stay turned off</fact11> during the physical exam. The patient's <fact12>cardiac exam demonstrates a normal rate and rhythm</fact12>, and his <fact13>pulmonary exam is clear to auscultation bilaterally</fact13>. <fact14>Musculoskeletal exam reveals diminished mobility of the neck in all four directions</fact14>, with <fact15>flexion of the neck causing the patient discomfort</fact15>. <fact16>Lumbar puncture is performed</fact16> and results are seen below.

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF):
<fact17>Cell count: 175/mm^3</fact17>
<fact18>Cl-: 119 mEq/L</fact18>
<fact19>Glucose: 49 mg/dL</fact19>
<fact20>Pressure: 150 mmH2O</fact20>
<fact21>Total protein: 55 mg/dL</fact21>

Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient's most likely diagnosis?

Answer: Analyzing the patient's symptoms, including <fact2>fever, nausea, and vomiting</fact2> that started <fact3>last night</fact3>, along with the physical exam findings of <fact14>diminished mobility of the neck</fact14> and <fact15>flexion of the neck causing discomfort</fact15>, suggests a diagnosis of meningitis. The results of the <fact16>lumbar puncture</fact16> further support this diagnosis, with an elevated <fact17>cell count</fact17>, decreased <fact19>glucose</fact19>, and increased <fact20>pressure</fact20> and <fact21>total protein</fact21> in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Given these findings, the best treatment for this patient's most likely diagnosis of bacterial meningitis would be antibiotics. Among the options provided, choice D, <fact22>Ceftriaxone and vancomycin</fact22>, is the most appropriate choice as it covers a broad spectrum of bacteria that can cause meningitis, including Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis.

question:
A 23-year-old man presents to his primary care physician after bleeding from his gums while brushing his teeth for the past week. Although he has had gum bleeding in the past, it has never been this severe. He has no family history available as he was adopted. He does not have any significant past medical history. His physical exam is within normal limits. Screening lab work is ordered with the following values:
Platelet count 330,000/mm3
Bleeding time 6 mins
Prothrombin time 12 sec
Activated partial thromboplastin time 42 sec
Factor VIII activity decreased
Ristocetin cofactor assay decreased
He is subsequently referred to a hematologist for further work-up and treatment. Which of the following aspects of coagulation would most likely be affected?
A) Factor IX
B) Gp Ib
C) Factor XI
D) Vitamin K
E) Antithrombin III
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>23-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care physician after <fact2>bleeding from his gums while brushing his teeth for the past week</fact2>. Although he has had gum bleeding in the past, it has never been this severe. He has no family history available as he was adopted. He does not have any significant past medical history. His physical exam is within normal limits. Screening lab work is ordered with the following values: <fact3>Platelet count 330,000/mm3</fact3>, <fact4>Bleeding time 6 mins</fact4>, <fact5>Prothrombin time 12 sec</fact5>, <fact6>Activated partial thromboplastin time 42 sec</fact6>, <fact7>Factor VIII activity decreased</fact7>, and <fact8>Ristocetin cofactor assay decreased</fact8>. He is subsequently referred to a hematologist for further work-up and treatment. Which of the following aspects of coagulation would most likely be affected?

Answer: Based on the provided information, particularly the <fact7>decreased Factor VIII activity</fact7> and <fact8>decreased Ristocetin cofactor assay</fact8>, the most likely affected aspect of coagulation is related to the function of von Willebrand factor (vWF), which is closely associated with Factor VIII. vWF acts as a carrier protein for Factor VIII and also plays a crucial role in platelet adhesion through its interaction with the Gp Ib receptor on platelets. Given these details, the correct answer is {B} Gp Ib, as it is directly related to the function of vWF, which is implicated by the decreased Ristocetin cofactor assay, a test used to assess the function of vWF.

question:
A 2-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her concerned father. He states that ever since her uncomplicated delivery she has failed to gain weight, has had chronic diarrhea, and has had multiple bacterial and viral infections. During the course of the workup, an absent thymic shadow is noted and a lymph node biopsy demonstrates the absence of germinal centers. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
A) Defect in WASP gene
B) Defect in ATM gene
C) Adenosine deaminase deficiency
D) NADPH oxidase deficiency
E) Defect in BTK gene
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>2-month-old girl</fact1> is brought to the pediatrician by her concerned father. He states that ever since her <fact2>uncomplicated delivery</fact2> she has <fact3>failed to gain weight</fact3>, has had <fact4>chronic diarrhea</fact4>, and has had <fact5>multiple bacterial and viral infections</fact5>. During the course of the workup, an <fact6>absent thymic shadow</fact6> is noted and a <fact7>lymph node biopsy demonstrates the absence of germinal centers</fact7>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>2-month-old girl's</fact1> symptoms of <fact3>failure to gain weight</fact3>, <fact4>chronic diarrhea</fact4>, and <fact5>multiple bacterial and viral infections</fact5> since her <fact2>uncomplicated delivery</fact2>, along with the findings of an <fact6>absent thymic shadow</fact6> and a <fact7>lymph node biopsy demonstrating the absence of germinal centers</fact7>, the most likely cause of her symptoms is a severe immunodeficiency disorder. Among the options provided, adenosine deaminase deficiency is a condition that affects the development and function of lymphocytes, leading to severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). This condition is characterized by the absence of a thymic shadow on imaging and the absence of germinal centers in lymphoid tissues, consistent with the patient's presentation. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 14-year-old girl presents with sudden drooping of the right side of her face with drooling and excessive tearing. The patient’s mother says that the patient was recently in northern Maine and spent most of her time during the trip outdoors. Physical examination reveals a slight asymmetry of the facial muscles with an inability to whistle or close the right eye. A circular red rash with central clearing is present on the trunk. There is also decreased taste sensation. Which of the following most likely transmitted the organism responsible for this patient’s illness?
A) Ixodes scapularis
B) Tsetse fly
C) Culicidae
D) Dermacentor variabilis
E) Anopheles
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>14-year-old girl</fact1> presents with <fact2>sudden drooping of the right side of her face with drooling and excessive tearing</fact2>. The patient’s mother says that the patient was recently in <fact3>northern Maine</fact3> and spent most of her time during the trip <fact4>outdoors</fact4>. Physical examination reveals a <fact5>slight asymmetry of the facial muscles with an inability to whistle or close the right eye</fact5>. A <fact6>circular red rash with central clearing</fact6> is present on the trunk. There is also <fact7>decreased taste sensation</fact7>. Which of the following most likely transmitted the organism responsible for this patient’s illness?

A) Ixodes scapularis
B) Tsetse fly
C) Culicidae
D) Dermacentor variabilis
E) Anopheles

Answer: A)

question:
A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of fatigue for several weeks. The parents report that their son quit doing sports at school because of low energy. The patient's academic performance has declined recently. He spends most of his time in the basement playing video games and eating bowls of cereal. He has no history of serious illness. His mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis and his father has major depressive disorder. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows conjunctival pallor, inflammation and fissuring of the corners of the mouth, and concavity of the finger nails. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 76 μm3
Platelet count 290,000/mm3
Red cell distribution width 18% (N = 13%–15%)
Leukocyte count 7,000/mm3
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in treatment?"
A) Regular blood transfusions
B) Fluoxetine
C) Methylphenidate
D) Iron supplementation
E) Allogenic stem cell transplantation
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>16-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of <fact2>fatigue for several weeks</fact2>. The parents report that their son quit doing sports at school because of <fact3>low energy</fact3>. The patient's academic performance has declined recently. He spends most of his time in the basement playing video games and eating bowls of cereal. He has no history of serious illness. His mother has <fact4>Hashimoto's thyroiditis</fact4> and his father has <fact5>major depressive disorder</fact5>. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows <fact6>conjunctival pallor</fact6>, <fact7>inflammation and fissuring of the corners of the mouth</fact7>, and <fact8>concavity of the finger nails</fact8>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin <fact9>11.5 g/dL</fact9>
Mean corpuscular volume <fact10>76 μm3</fact10>
Platelet count <fact11>290,000/mm3</fact11>
Red cell distribution width <fact12>18% (N = 13%–15%)</fact12>
Leukocyte count <fact13>7,000/mm3</fact13>
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in treatment?

Answer: The patient's presentation with <fact2>fatigue for several weeks</fact2> and <fact3>low energy</fact3> along with laboratory findings of low <fact9>hemoglobin (11.5 g/dL)</fact9> and <fact10>mean corpuscular volume (76 μm3)</fact10> suggests iron deficiency anemia. The physical examination findings of <fact6>conjunctival pallor</fact6>, <fact7>inflammation and fissuring of the corners of the mouth</fact7>, and <fact8>concavity of the finger nails</fact8> further support this diagnosis. Given these factors, the most appropriate initial step in treatment is iron supplementation to address the underlying cause of his anemia and fatigue. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 78-year-old right-handed man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter for sudden onset speech changes. The patient lives with his daughter and was chatting with her when suddenly his speech became distorted with random and disconnected words that made no sense. He seems to be physically frustrated that no one understands him. Physical examination demonstrates weakness of the right arm. Damage to which location would best explain this patient’s symptoms?
A) Left frontal lobe
B) Left internal capsule
C) Left temporal lobe
D) Right frontal lobe
E) Right temporal lobe
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>78-year-old right-handed man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by his daughter for <fact2>sudden onset speech changes</fact2>. The patient lives with his daughter and was chatting with her when suddenly his <fact3>speech became distorted with random and disconnected words that made no sense</fact3>. He seems to be physically frustrated that no one understands him. Physical examination demonstrates <fact4>weakness of the right arm</fact4>. Damage to which location would best explain this patient’s symptoms?
A) Left frontal lobe
B) Left internal capsule
C) Left temporal lobe
D) Right frontal lobe
E) Right temporal lobe

Answer: 
The patient's symptoms of <fact2>sudden onset speech changes</fact2> with <fact3>speech becoming distorted with random and disconnected words that made no sense</fact3> are indicative of expressive aphasia, which is typically associated with damage to the frontal lobe, specifically Broca's area. Additionally, the patient exhibits <fact4>weakness of the right arm</fact4>, which suggests contralateral motor control involvement. Since the patient is <fact1>right-handed</fact1>, it is likely that the left hemisphere of the brain is dominant for language and motor functions. Therefore, the location that best explains this patient's symptoms is the <fact5>left frontal lobe</fact5>, which is responsible for language production and motor control of the right arm. The answer is {A}.

question:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of intermittent chest pain and palpitations. She also complains of dyspnea on exertion and has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss in the past 2 months despite normal appetite. She has no history of serious medical illness. Cardiac examination shows an irregularly irregular rhythm and a grade 3/6, low pitched, rumbling, mid-diastolic murmur heard best over the apex. Diffuse wheezing and bilateral rales are present in the lung bases. A transthoracic echocardiogram shows a left-ventricular ejection fraction of 40% and a mass in the left atrium. A biopsy of the mass is likely to show which of the following?
A) Nonencapsulated groups of well-differentiated skeletal muscle cells
B) Clusters of bland cells without mitotic activity
C) Mixture of cells from different germinal layers
D) Encapsulated cluster of mature fat cells
E) Nests of atypical melanocytes
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the emergency department because of <fact2>intermittent chest pain and palpitations</fact2>. She also complains of <fact3>dyspnea on exertion</fact3> and has had a <fact4>4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss</fact4> in the past 2 months despite normal appetite. She has no history of serious medical illness. Cardiac examination shows an <fact5>irregularly irregular rhythm</fact5> and a <fact6>grade 3/6, low pitched, rumbling, mid-diastolic murmur</fact6> heard best over the apex. Diffuse <fact7>wheezing and bilateral rales</fact7> are present in the lung bases. A <fact8>transthoracic echocardiogram</fact8> shows a <fact9>left-ventricular ejection fraction of 40%</fact9> and a <fact10>mass in the left atrium</fact10>. A biopsy of the mass is likely to show which of the following?
A) Nonencapsulated groups of well-differentiated skeletal muscle cells
B) Clusters of bland cells without mitotic activity
C) Mixture of cells from different germinal layers
D) Encapsulated cluster of mature fat cells
E) Nests of atypical melanocytes

Answer: 
Given the patient's presentation with <fact2>intermittent chest pain and palpitations</fact2>, <fact3>dyspnea on exertion</fact3>, and a significant <fact4>weight loss</fact4> despite normal appetite, along with the cardiac examination findings of an <fact5>irregularly irregular rhythm</fact5> and a <fact6>grade 3/6, low pitched, rumbling, mid-diastolic murmur</fact6>, and the echocardiogram showing a <fact9>left-ventricular ejection fraction of 40%</fact9> and a <fact10>mass in the left atrium</fact10>, the clinical picture suggests atrial myxoma. Atrial myxomas are benign tumors that can cause obstructive symptoms and embolic events. The histological appearance of an atrial myxoma typically shows clusters of bland cells without mitotic activity, which corresponds to option B.

question:
A 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 38 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital for active labor. The pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes and fetal weight is estimated to be at the 90th percentile for gestational age. During delivery, there is an arrest in the second stage of labor, and a vacuum-assisted delivery is performed. Postpartum examination shows a third-degree laceration in the vagina extending into the perineum at the 6 o'clock position. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following complications?
A) Urge incontinence
B) Vesicovaginal fistula
C) Fecal incontinence
D) Small bowel obstruction
E) Stress incontinence
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0</fact1>, at <fact2>38 weeks' gestation</fact2> is admitted to the hospital for <fact3>active labor</fact3>. The pregnancy was complicated by <fact4>gestational diabetes</fact4> and <fact5>fetal weight is estimated to be at the 90th percentile for gestational age</fact5>. During delivery, there is an <fact6>arrest in the second stage of labor</fact6>, and a <fact7>vacuum-assisted delivery</fact7> is performed. Postpartum examination shows a <fact8>third-degree laceration in the vagina extending into the perineum at the 6 o'clock position</fact8>. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following complications?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact8>third-degree laceration in the vagina extending into the perineum at the 6 o'clock position</fact8> following a <fact7>vacuum-assisted delivery</fact7> due to an <fact6>arrest in the second stage of labor</fact6>, the most likely complication is related to the integrity and function of the anal sphincter. A third-degree laceration involves the anal sphincter complex, which can lead to issues with fecal continence. Therefore, the patient is most likely to experience <fact9>fecal incontinence</fact9> as a complication. The answer is {C}.

question:
A 36-year-old woman presents with increased tiredness and lethargy for the past 4 weeks. Investigations show her hemoglobin level to be 8.6 gm/dL and serum creatinine of 4.6 mg/dL. The serum is negative for antinuclear antibodies (ANA) and positive for C3 nephritic factor. Urinalysis shows a 3+ proteinuria. The renal biopsy demonstrates hypercellular glomerulus with electron dense deposits along the glomerular basement membrane. What is the most likely cause?
A) Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)
B) Membrano proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN)
C) Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN)
D) Minimal change disease
E) Membranous glomerulonephritis (MGN)
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>36-year-old woman</fact1> presents with <fact2>increased tiredness and lethargy</fact2> for the past <fact3>4 weeks</fact3>. Investigations show her <fact4>hemoglobin level to be 8.6 gm/dL</fact4> and <fact5>serum creatinine of 4.6 mg/dL</fact5>. The serum is <fact6>negative for antinuclear antibodies (ANA)</fact6> and <fact7>positive for C3 nephritic factor</fact7>. Urinalysis shows a <fact8>3+ proteinuria</fact8>. The renal biopsy demonstrates <fact9>hypercellular glomerulus with electron dense deposits along the glomerular basement membrane</fact9>. What is the most likely cause?

Answer: 
The patient's presentation of <fact2>increased tiredness and lethargy</fact2> along with laboratory findings of a low <fact4>hemoglobin level</fact4> and elevated <fact5>serum creatinine</fact5> suggests a severe kidney condition. The <fact6>negative ANA</fact6> rules out autoimmune causes such as lupus nephritis. The presence of <fact7>C3 nephritic factor</fact7> is indicative of an alternative complement pathway dysregulation, which is commonly seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). The <fact8>3+ proteinuria</fact8> and renal biopsy findings of <fact9>hypercellular glomerulus with electron dense deposits along the glomerular basement membrane</fact9> further support this diagnosis. Therefore, the most likely cause is {B}.

question:
A 67-year-old man with peripheral neuropathy comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after the results of serum protein electrophoresis showed monoclonal gammopathy. A complete blood count, serum creatinine, and serum electrolyte concentrations are within the reference ranges. A bone marrow biopsy shows 6% monoclonal plasma cells. Further analysis shows that class I major histocompatibility molecules are downregulated in these monoclonal plasma cells. The proliferation of these monoclonal plasma cells is normally prevented by a class of immune cells that lyse abnormal cells without the need for opsonization, priming, or prior activation. Which of the following best describes this class of immune cells?
A) CD8+ T lymphocytes
B) Bone marrow-derived macrophages
C) CD4+ T lymphocytes
D) Natural killer cells
E) Band neutrophils
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>67-year-old man</fact1> with <fact2>peripheral neuropathy</fact2> comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after the results of <fact3>serum protein electrophoresis showed monoclonal gammopathy</fact3>. A complete blood count, serum creatinine, and serum electrolyte concentrations are within the reference ranges. A <fact4>bone marrow biopsy shows 6% monoclonal plasma cells</fact4>. Further analysis shows that <fact5>class I major histocompatibility molecules are downregulated in these monoclonal plasma cells</fact5>. The proliferation of these monoclonal plasma cells is normally prevented by a class of immune cells that <fact6>lyse abnormal cells without the need for opsonization, priming, or prior activation</fact6>. Which of the following best describes this class of immune cells?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>67-year-old man's</fact1> condition with <fact2>peripheral neuropathy</fact2> and the presence of <fact3>monoclonal gammopathy</fact3> as indicated by serum protein electrophoresis, the bone marrow biopsy showing <fact4>6% monoclonal plasma cells</fact4> suggests a plasma cell disorder. The downregulation of <fact5>class I major histocompatibility molecules</fact5> in these cells indicates an attempt to evade immune surveillance. The class of immune cells that can <fact6>lyse abnormal cells without the need for opsonization, priming, or prior activation</fact6> are natural killer (NK) cells. NK cells are crucial for recognizing and eliminating cells that have downregulated major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I expression, which is a common mechanism used by tumor cells and virus-infected cells to evade immune detection. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of frequent headaches, double vision, fatigue, and myalgias. Physical examination shows pallor, tenderness to palpation over the temples, and inward deviation of the left eye. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 65 mm/h. Temporal artery biopsy shows transmural granulomatous inflammation and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina. Treatment with high-dose intravenous corticosteroids is begun. The patient's condition puts her at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
A) Pulmonary hypertension
B) Lower extremity gangrene
C) Palpable purpura
D) Posterior uveitis
E) Thoracic aortic aneurysm
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>72-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of a <fact2>1-month history of frequent headaches, double vision, fatigue, and myalgias</fact2>. Physical examination shows <fact3>pallor, tenderness to palpation over the temples</fact3>, and <fact4>inward deviation of the left eye</fact4>. Laboratory studies show an <fact5>erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 65 mm/h</fact5>. Temporal artery biopsy shows <fact6>transmural granulomatous inflammation and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina</fact6>. Treatment with <fact7>high-dose intravenous corticosteroids</fact7> is begun. The patient's condition puts her at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's condition, characterized by a <fact2>1-month history of frequent headaches, double vision, fatigue, and myalgias</fact2>, along with physical examination findings of <fact3>pallor, tenderness to palpation over the temples</fact3>, and <fact4>inward deviation of the left eye</fact4>, and laboratory results showing an <fact5>erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 65 mm/h</fact5>, the diagnosis is Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA). The presence of <fact6>transmural granulomatous inflammation and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina</fact6> on temporal artery biopsy further supports this diagnosis. GCA is a form of large vessel vasculitis that can lead to serious complications, including visual loss and aortic aneurysm. Given the patient's age and the nature of GCA, the complication she is at greatest risk of developing is a <fact8>thoracic aortic aneurysm</fact8>. Therefore, the correct answer is {E}.

question:
A 4-year-old previously healthy boy presents with 4 days of intermittent vomiting and 5-6 daily loose stools. His mother noted bloody stools and decreased oral intake of food and water over the last 24 hours. He is normally in daycare; however, he has been home for the past 3 days. On physical exam his temperature is 102.2°F (39°C), blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min and O2 saturation is 99% on room air. He has dry mucous membranes. On abdominal exam you note diffuse tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding. There are no masses, hepatosplenomegaly, and bowel sounds are hyperactive. Ultrasound of the right lower quadrant is negative for appendicitis. Stool is guaiac positive. He receives 15mg/kg acetaminophen and fluids are started. The next day, he complains of lower extremity weakness and tingling. On repeat exam, lower extremity strength is 3/5 with diminished patellar deep tendon reflexes. Which of the following lab findings would most likely be seen in this patient?
A) Gram stain positive CSF
B) Peripheral eosinophilia
C) Xanthochromia on cerebrospinal fluid analysis
D) Increased cerebrospinal fluid protein with normal cell count
E) Oligoclonal bands on cerebrospinal fluid analysis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>4-year-old previously healthy boy</fact1> presents with <fact2>4 days of intermittent vomiting and 5-6 daily loose stools</fact2>. His mother noted <fact3>bloody stools and decreased oral intake of food and water over the last 24 hours</fact3>. He is normally in daycare; however, he has been home for the past <fact4>3 days</fact4>. On physical exam his <fact5>temperature is 102.2°F (39°C)</fact5>, <fact6>blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg</fact6>, <fact7>pulse is 120/min</fact7>, <fact8>respirations are 22/min</fact8> and <fact9>O2 saturation is 99% on room air</fact9>. He has <fact10>dry mucous membranes</fact10>. On abdominal exam you note <fact11>diffuse tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding</fact11>. There are no masses, <fact12>hepatosplenomegaly</fact12>, and <fact13>bowel sounds are hyperactive</fact13>. Ultrasound of the <fact14>right lower quadrant is negative for appendicitis</fact14>. <fact15>Stool is guaiac positive</fact15>. He receives <fact16>15mg/kg acetaminophen</fact16> and fluids are started. The next day, he complains of <fact17>lower extremity weakness and tingling</fact17>. On repeat exam, <fact18>lower extremity strength is 3/5 with diminished patellar deep tendon reflexes</fact18>. Which of the following lab findings would most likely be seen in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation of <fact2>4 days of intermittent vomiting and 5-6 daily loose stools</fact2> with <fact3>bloody stools and decreased oral intake of food and water</fact3>, along with the development of <fact17>lower extremity weakness and tingling</fact17> and <fact18>lower extremity strength is 3/5 with diminished patellar deep tendon reflexes</fact18> after receiving <fact16>15mg/kg acetaminophen</fact16> and fluids, it suggests a possible complication related to the initial gastrointestinal symptoms and the subsequent neurological findings. The most likely diagnosis is Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), an autoimmune disorder that can be triggered by infections, including gastrointestinal infections. Among the provided options, the increased cerebrospinal fluid protein with normal cell count (D) is a characteristic finding in GBS. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A stillborn infant is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 32-year-old woman. The mother had no prenatal care. Examination of the stillborn shows a small pelvis, shallow intergluteal cleft, and club feet. An x-ray shows the absence of the sacrum and lumbar vertebrae. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
A) Maternal oligohydramnios
B) Intrauterine alcohol exposure
C) Chromosome 13 trisomy
D) Maternal diabetes
E) Chromosome 18 trisomy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A stillborn infant is delivered at <fact1>38 weeks' gestation</fact1> to a <fact2>32-year-old woman</fact2>. The mother had <fact3>no prenatal care</fact3>. Examination of the stillborn shows a <fact4>small pelvis, shallow intergluteal cleft, and club feet</fact4>. An x-ray shows the <fact5>absence of the sacrum and lumbar vertebrae</fact5>. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact4>small pelvis, shallow intergluteal cleft, and club feet</fact4> observed in the stillborn infant, along with the <fact5>absence of the sacrum and lumbar vertebrae</fact5> seen on x-ray, the condition is suggestive of caudal dysplasia or sacral agenesis. Among the options provided, maternal diabetes is a known risk factor for caudal dysplasia. Therefore, the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition is {D}.

question:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine bone mineral density screening. She does not have any children. Menopause was at age 55. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 48 years. She has hypertension for which she takes ramipril. Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry at the femoral neck shows a T-score of -2.7 SD. The physician considers treatment with raloxifene. This medication would put her at increased risk of developing which of the following conditions?
A) Pulmonary embolism
B) Cellulitis
C) Breast cancer
D) Mandibular osteonecrosis
E) Hypercholesterolemia
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>65-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for a routine <fact2>bone mineral density screening</fact2>. She does not have any children. Menopause was at age <fact3>55</fact3>. Her mother died of <fact4>breast cancer</fact4> at the age of <fact5>48 years</fact5>. She has <fact6>hypertension</fact6> for which she takes <fact7>ramipril</fact7>. Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry at the femoral neck shows a <fact8>T-score of -2.7 SD</fact8>. The physician considers treatment with <fact9>raloxifene</fact9>. This medication would put her at increased risk of developing which of the following conditions?

Answer: 
Given the patient's profile, including her <fact1>age</fact1>, <fact3>age at menopause</fact3>, and <fact8>T-score indicating osteoporosis</fact8>, the physician is considering treatment with <fact9>raloxifene</fact9>, a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) known for its use in treating osteoporosis and reducing the risk of <fact4>breast cancer</fact4>. However, SERMs like <fact9>raloxifene</fact9> are also associated with an increased risk of thromboembolic events. Therefore, the medication would put her at increased risk of developing <fact10>pulmonary embolism</fact10>. The answer is {A}.

question:
Two weeks after undergoing an emergency cardiac catherization with stenting for unstable angina pectoris, a 61-year-old man has decreased urinary output and malaise. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoarthritis of the hips. Prior to admission, his medications were insulin and naproxen. He was also started on aspirin, clopidogrel, and metoprolol after the coronary intervention. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 93/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. Examination shows mottled, reticulated purplish discoloration of the feet. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin count 14 g/dL
Leukocyte count 16,400/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 56%
Eosinophils 11%
Lymphocytes 31%
Monocytes 2%
Platelet count 260,000/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 68 mm/h
Serum
Urea nitrogen 25 mg/dL
Creatinine 4.2 mg/dL
Renal biopsy shows intravascular spindle-shaped vacuoles. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?"
A) Renal papillary necrosis
B) Allergic interstitial nephritis
C) Cholesterol embolization
D) Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis
E) Polyarteritis nodosa
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>61-year-old man</fact1> has <fact2>decreased urinary output and malaise</fact2> two weeks after undergoing an <fact3>emergency cardiac catherization with stenting for unstable angina pectoris</fact3>. He has <fact4>type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoarthritis of the hips</fact4>. Prior to admission, his medications were <fact5>insulin and naproxen</fact5>. He was also started on <fact6>aspirin, clopidogrel, and metoprolol</fact6> after the coronary intervention. His <fact7>temperature is 38°C (100.4°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 93/min</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg</fact9>. Examination shows <fact10>mottled, reticulated purplish discoloration of the feet</fact10>. Laboratory studies show:
<fact11>Hemoglobin count 14 g/dL</fact11>
<fact12>Leukocyte count 16,400/mm3</fact12>
<fact13>Segmented neutrophils 56%</fact13>
<fact14>Eosinophils 11%</fact14>
<fact15>Lymphocytes 31%</fact15>
<fact16>Monocytes 2%</fact16>
<fact17>Platelet count 260,000/mm3</fact17>
<fact18>Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 68 mm/h</fact18>
<fact19>Serum urea nitrogen 25 mg/dL</fact19>
<fact20>Serum creatinine 4.2 mg/dL</fact20>
<fact21>Renal biopsy shows intravascular spindle-shaped vacuoles</fact21>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>61-year-old man's</fact1> recent <fact3>emergency cardiac catherization with stenting for unstable angina pectoris</fact3> and the development of <fact2>decreased urinary output and malaise</fact2>, along with the presence of <fact10>mottled, reticulated purplish discoloration of the feet</fact10> and the laboratory findings, including <fact20>serum creatinine 4.2 mg/dL</fact20> and <fact21>renal biopsy showing intravascular spindle-shaped vacuoles</fact21>, the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is cholesterol embolization. This condition is a known complication of cardiac catheterization and can lead to renal failure and skin manifestations as seen in this patient. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 7 -day-old newborn boy presents to the emergency department with a history of fever, irritability, and generalized erythema. During the first 2 days of clinical manifestations, the parents of the child tried to control the symptoms using acetaminophen; however, the newborn continued to be ill, and blisters were noticeable around the buttocks, hands, and feet. During the physical examination, the vital signs include body temperature 39.0°C (102.3°F), heart rate 130/min, and respiratory rate 45/min. Ears, nose, and oral mucosa preserved their integrity, while the skin presents with diffuse blanching erythema and flaccid blisters with a positive Nikolsky’s sign. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Scarlet fever
B) Scalded skin syndrome
C) Impetigo
D) Erysipela
E) Pyoderma
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>7-day-old newborn boy</fact1> presents to the emergency department with a history of <fact2>fever, irritability, and generalized erythema</fact2>. During the first <fact3>2 days</fact3> of clinical manifestations, the parents of the child tried to control the symptoms using <fact4>acetaminophen</fact4>; however, the newborn continued to be ill, and <fact5>blisters were noticeable around the buttocks, hands, and feet</fact5>. During the physical examination, the vital signs include <fact6>body temperature 39.0°C (102.3°F)</fact6>, <fact7>heart rate 130/min</fact7>, and <fact8>respiratory rate 45/min</fact8>. <fact9>Ears, nose, and oral mucosa preserved their integrity</fact9>, while the <fact10>skin presents with diffuse blanching erythema and flaccid blisters with a positive Nikolsky’s sign</fact10>. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>7-day-old newborn boy</fact1> with a history of <fact2>fever, irritability, and generalized erythema</fact2> and the presence of <fact5>blisters around the buttocks, hands, and feet</fact5>, along with a <fact10>positive Nikolsky’s sign</fact10>, the most likely diagnosis is {B} Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS). SSSS is a condition caused by staphylococcal toxins that typically affects newborns and young children, leading to the formation of blisters and peeling skin. The fact that the <fact9>ears, nose, and oral mucosa preserved their integrity</fact9> further supports this diagnosis, as SSSS tends to spare these areas.

question:
A 25-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of a "painful mass in my left groin." She says that her symptoms began 4 days ago as a painful mass that slowly enlarged, ruptured, and ulcerated. However, she denies fever, chills, dysuria, or hematuria. Three weeks prior to her current symptoms she noted a small, painless ulcer on her labium majorum that resolved after a few days. She admits to having unprotected sex with a male partner a month ago while she was traveling in Southeast Asia. Temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 139/84 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination is significant for left-sided, tender, ulcerative lymph nodes with a dark discoloration. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient's condition?
A) Donovan bodies on Wright-Giemsa stain
B) Gram-negative rods in school of fish formation on Gram stain
C) PCR positive for Chlamydia trachomatis
D) Positive RPR, VDRL, and FTA-ABS
E) Tzanck smear with multinucleated giant cells
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old woman</fact1> presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of a <fact2>"painful mass in my left groin."</fact2> She says that her symptoms began <fact3>4 days ago</fact3> as a <fact4>painful mass that slowly enlarged, ruptured, and ulcerated.</fact4> However, she denies <fact5>fever, chills, dysuria, or hematuria.</fact5> <fact6>Three weeks prior to her current symptoms</fact6> she noted a <fact7>small, painless ulcer on her labium majorum</fact7> that resolved after a few days. She admits to having <fact8>unprotected sex with a male partner a month ago</fact8> while she was traveling in <fact9>Southeast Asia.</fact9> Temperature is <fact10>99°F (37.2°C)</fact10>, blood pressure is <fact11>139/84 mmHg</fact11>, pulse is <fact12>76/min</fact12>, and respirations are <fact13>18/min</fact13>. Physical examination is significant for <fact14>left-sided, tender, ulcerative lymph nodes with a dark discoloration.</fact14> Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient's condition?

Answer: A) Donovan bodies on Wright-Giemsa stain. The patient's symptoms of a <fact4>painful mass that slowly enlarged, ruptured, and ulcerated</fact4> in the groin area, accompanied by a history of a <fact7>small, painless ulcer on her labium majorum</fact7> and <fact8>unprotected sex with a male partner a month ago</fact8> in <fact9>Southeast Asia</fact9>, are indicative of Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). The presence of <fact14>left-sided, tender, ulcerative lymph nodes with a dark discoloration</fact14> further supports this diagnosis. Donovan bodies, which are the causative organisms of LGV (Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1-L3), can be identified on Wright-Giemsa stain.

question:
A 22-year-old woman with a history of asthma visits her physician for worsening shortness of breath. She states that she feels as though her “lungs are falling apart,” noting that her lung function has been steadily deteriorating. She further states that she has visited a number of other physicians who prescribed several different types of inhalers, but she feels that they have not helped her control her asthma exacerbations. She has experienced 4 episodes of pneumonia in the last 3 years and often suffers from “random” bouts of excessive coughing and wheezing. When asked if her coughing episodes produce sputum, she states, “Yes, the stuff is greenish with specks of red in it.” She also states that her coughing and wheezing episodes are associated with fever, malaise, and occasional expectoration of brown mucous plugs. The vital signs include: blood pressure 122/70 mm Hg, pulse 66/min, respiratory rate 26/min, and temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F). On physical exam, the patient appears frail-looking and in moderate respiratory distress. Auscultation reveals inspiratory crackles in the right lung base and coarse breath sounds in the bilateral upper lung lobes. Chest radiograph, as shown below, reveals atelectasis in the right lung base. There are also branched radiodensities that the radiologist notes as being “glove-finger shadows” (noted by the arrow in the image). Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels are elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy in this patient?
A) Isoniazid
B) Fluconazole
C) Caspofungin
D) Prednisone
E) Surgical resection of the infiltrates
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>22-year-old woman</fact1> with a history of <fact2>asthma</fact2> visits her physician for <fact3>worsening shortness of breath</fact3>. She states that she feels as though her “lungs are falling apart,” noting that her <fact4>lung function has been steadily deteriorating</fact4>. She further states that she has visited a number of other physicians who prescribed several different types of <fact5>inhalers</fact5>, but she feels that they have not helped her control her <fact6>asthma exacerbations</fact6>. She has experienced <fact7>4 episodes of pneumonia</fact7> in the last 3 years and often suffers from “random” bouts of excessive <fact8>coughing and wheezing</fact8>. When asked if her <fact9>coughing episodes produce sputum</fact9>, she states, “Yes, the stuff is <fact10>greenish with specks of red in it</fact10>.” She also states that her <fact11>coughing and wheezing episodes are associated with fever, malaise, and occasional expectoration of brown mucous plugs</fact11>. The vital signs include: <fact12>blood pressure 122/70 mm Hg</fact12>, <fact13>pulse 66/min</fact13>, <fact14>respiratory rate 26/min</fact14>, and <fact15>temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact15>. On physical exam, the patient appears <fact16>frail-looking and in moderate respiratory distress</fact16>. Auscultation reveals <fact17>inspiratory crackles in the right lung base and coarse breath sounds in the bilateral upper lung lobes</fact17>. Chest radiograph, as shown below, reveals <fact18>atelectasis in the right lung base</fact18>. There are also <fact19>branched radiodensities that the radiologist notes as being “glove-finger shadows”</fact19> (noted by the arrow in the image). <fact20>Serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels are elevated</fact20>. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy in this patient?

Answer: Based on the patient's history of <fact2>asthma</fact2>, <fact4>steadily deteriorating lung function</fact4>, <fact7>recurrent episodes of pneumonia</fact7>, and <fact8>excessive coughing and wheezing</fact8>, along with the presence of <fact10>greenish sputum with specks of red</fact10> and <fact11>fever, malaise, and expectoration of brown mucous plugs</fact11>, the patient's condition is suggestive of an allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) or a fungal infection. The elevated <fact20>serum immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels</fact20> further support this diagnosis. Considering the patient's frail condition and moderate respiratory distress (<fact16>frail-looking and in moderate respiratory distress</fact16>), the most appropriate therapy would be to manage the patient's symptoms and control the fungal infection. Among the options provided, Prednisone is an anti-inflammatory medication that can help manage the patient's symptoms and is often used in conjunction with antifungal medications. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 30-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of infertility. He and his wife have been trying to get pregnant for the past two years. They have used fertility monitors and other aids without success. A hysterosalpingogram in his wife was normal. The patient has a history of cleft lip and recurrent upper respiratory infections as a child. He was briefly hospitalized for severe pneumonia when he was 9-years-old. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 18/min. On examination, he is a healthy-appearing male in no acute distress with fully developed reproductive organs. Notably, cardiac auscultation is silent in the left 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. This patient most likely has a mutation in which of the following classes of proteins?
A) Microtubule monomeric protein
B) Lysosomal trafficking regulator protein
C) Transmembrane ion channel protein
D) Retrograde cytoskeletal motor protein
E) Anterograde cytoskeletal motor protein
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>30-year-old male</fact1> presents to his primary care physician complaining of <fact2>infertility</fact2>. He and his wife have been trying to get pregnant for the past <fact3>two years</fact3>. They have used fertility monitors and other aids without success. A <fact4>hysterosalpingogram in his wife was normal</fact4>. The patient has a history of <fact5>cleft lip</fact5> and <fact6>recurrent upper respiratory infections</fact6> as a child. He was briefly hospitalized for <fact7>severe pneumonia</fact7> when he was 9-years-old. His <fact8>temperature is 98.6°F (37°C)</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 90/min</fact10>, and <fact11>respirations are 18/min</fact11>. On examination, he is a healthy-appearing male in no acute distress with <fact12>fully developed reproductive organs</fact12>. Notably, <fact13>cardiac auscultation is silent in the left 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line</fact13>. This patient most likely has a mutation in which of the following classes of proteins?
A) Microtubule monomeric protein
B) Lysosomal trafficking regulator protein
C) Transmembrane ion channel protein
D) Retrograde cytoskeletal motor protein
E) Anterograde cytoskeletal motor protein

Answer: 
Given the patient's presentation, specifically the <fact2>infertility</fact2> and <fact13>silent cardiac auscultation in the left 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line</fact13>, it suggests a condition that affects both reproductive and cardiac systems. Additionally, the patient's history of <fact5>cleft lip</fact5>, <fact6>recurrent upper respiratory infections</fact6>, and <fact7>severe pneumonia</fact7> in childhood, points towards a condition that affects multiple systems. This constellation of symptoms is highly suggestive of Kartagener syndrome, a condition characterized by situs inversus, bronchiectasis, and infertility due to ciliary dysfunction. The underlying cause of Kartagener syndrome is a mutation in the DNAI1 gene, which encodes for a dynein protein, a type of <fact14>anterograde cytoskeletal motor protein</fact14> crucial for ciliary function. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a painless right-sided scrotal swelling. The swelling started several weeks ago but is not always present. Physical examination shows an 8-cm, soft, cystic nontender right-sided scrotal mass that transilluminates. The mass does not increase in size on coughing and it is possible to palpate normal tissue above the mass. There are no bowel sounds in the mass, and it does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position. Examination of the testis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the mass?
A) Imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by tunica vaginalis
B) Failure of processus vaginalis to obliterate
C) Extension of abdominal contents through the inguinal canal
D) Dilation and tortuosity of veins in the pampiniform plexus
E) Primary germ cell neoplasia of the testicle
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>52-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician for the evaluation of a <fact2>painless right-sided scrotal swelling</fact2>. The <fact3>swelling started several weeks ago but is not always present</fact3>. Physical examination shows an <fact4>8-cm, soft, cystic nontender right-sided scrotal mass</fact4> that <fact5>transilluminates</fact5>. The mass does not <fact6>increase in size on coughing</fact6> and it is possible to <fact7>palpate normal tissue above the mass</fact7>. There are <fact8>no bowel sounds in the mass</fact8>, and it does not <fact9>reduce when the patient is in a supine position</fact9>. Examination of the testis shows <fact10>no abnormalities</fact10>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the mass?

Answer: 
Considering the characteristics of the mass, such as being <fact4>soft, cystic, and nontender</fact4>, <fact5>transilluminating</fact5>, and not increasing in size on coughing (<fact6>no increase in size on coughing</fact6>), along with the absence of bowel sounds in the mass (<fact8>no bowel sounds in the mass</fact8>) and the ability to palpate normal tissue above the mass (<fact7>palpate normal tissue above the mass</fact7>), it suggests a hydrocele. A hydrocele is a fluid-filled sac in the scrotum that results from an <fact11>imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis</fact11>. The fact that the mass does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position (<fact9>does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position</fact9>) and that there are no abnormalities of the testis itself (<fact10>no abnormalities</fact10>) further supports this diagnosis. Therefore, the most likely cause of the mass is {A}.

question:
A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive muscle weakness for five months. She feels that the muscles in her shoulders and hips have been getting weaker and sometimes feel sore. She now has difficulty getting up from chairs, climbing stairs, and combing her hair. She has also noticed new difficulty with swallowing solid foods, but has no trouble with liquids. She has a 5-year history of hyperlipidemia controlled with fluvastatin. Her maternal uncle died at age 26 from Duchenne's muscular dystrophy and her mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows moderate weakness in the arm abductors and hip flexors bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.7 g/dL
Leukocytes 11,200/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 33 mm/h
Serum
Creatine kinase 212 U/L
Lactate dehydrogenase 164 U/L
AST 34 U/L
ALT 35 U/L
Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?"
A) Intrafascicular infiltration on muscle biopsy
B) Inflammation of synovial spaces on ultrasound
C) Perifascicular and perivascular infiltration on muscle biopsy
D) Positive anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies
E) Dystrophin gene mutation on genetic analysis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>47-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>progressive muscle weakness for five months</fact2>. She feels that the <fact3>muscles in her shoulders and hips have been getting weaker</fact3> and sometimes feel sore. She now has <fact4>difficulty getting up from chairs, climbing stairs, and combing her hair</fact4>. She has also noticed <fact5>new difficulty with swallowing solid foods, but has no trouble with liquids</fact5>. She has a <fact6>5-year history of hyperlipidemia controlled with fluvastatin</fact6>. Her <fact7>maternal uncle died at age 26 from Duchenne's muscular dystrophy</fact7> and her <fact8>mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis</fact8>. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows <fact9>moderate weakness in the arm abductors and hip flexors bilaterally</fact9>. Deep tendon reflexes are <fact10>2+ bilaterally</fact10>. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.7 g/dL
Leukocytes 11,200/mm3
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 33 mm/h
Serum
Creatine kinase 212 U/L
Lactate dehydrogenase 164 U/L
AST 34 U/L
ALT 35 U/L
Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

Answer: Analyzing the <fact1>47-year-old woman's</fact1> presentation of <fact2>progressive muscle weakness for five months</fact2>, specifically the <fact3>muscles in her shoulders and hips getting weaker</fact3> and <fact4>difficulty with daily activities</fact4>, along with <fact5>difficulty swallowing solid foods</fact5>, points towards a muscular dystrophy. The <fact7>maternal uncle's history of Duchenne's muscular dystrophy</fact7> suggests a possible genetic component. However, the patient's symptoms and laboratory results, including the elevated <fact11>creatine kinase and lactate dehydrogenase levels</fact11>, are more indicative of an inflammatory myopathy. Among the options provided, choice C, <fact12>perifascicular and perivascular infiltration on muscle biopsy</fact12>, is characteristic of dermatomyositis, a type of inflammatory myopathy. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 34-year-old patient is brought to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident. An EKG shows sinus tachycardia and chest radiograph reveals an enlarged cardiac silhouette. While observing sinus tachycardia on the patient's telemetry, you note that the radial pulse cannot be palpated during inspiration. What should be the next step in management of this patient?
A) IV Heparin
B) Pericardiocentesis
C) Chest CT scan
D) Pericardial window
E) Insert chest tube
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>34-year-old patient</fact1> is brought to the emergency room after a <fact2>motor vehicle accident</fact2>. An <fact3>EKG shows sinus tachycardia</fact3> and <fact4>chest radiograph reveals an enlarged cardiac silhouette</fact4>. While observing <fact5>sinus tachycardia</fact5> on the patient's telemetry, you note that the <fact6>radial pulse cannot be palpated during inspiration</fact6>. What should be the next step in management of this patient?

Answer: Based on the information provided, the patient's presentation is highly suggestive of cardiac tamponade, a life-threatening condition that requires immediate intervention. The <fact4>enlarged cardiac silhouette</fact4> on the chest radiograph, along with the <fact5>sinus tachycardia</fact5> and the inability to palpate the <fact6>radial pulse during inspiration</fact6> (pulsus paradoxus), are all classic signs of cardiac tamponade. Given the urgent need to relieve the pressure on the heart, the most appropriate next step in management is to perform a <fact7>pericardiocentesis</fact7>, a procedure where fluid is aspirated from the pericardial sac to alleviate the tamponade. Therefore, the correct answer is {B}.

question:
A 51-year-old Asian woman presents to her primary care provider with abdominal pain. On examination, she is found to have rebound tenderness in the lower right quadrant of her abdomen. Further workup suggests ovarian cancer, which is confirmed later in the week to be stage 4 with confirmed distant metastases in the lungs and brain. Which of the following routes describes the most likely lymphatic route for this malignancy to have metastasized to the brain?
A) Sentinel node - left lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - right bronchomediastinal trunk - right lymphatic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
B) Sentinel node - left lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - left subclavian vein - systemic circulation
C) Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - right bronchomediastinal trunk - right lymphatic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
D) Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
E) Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - left subclavian vein - systemic circulation
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>51-year-old Asian woman</fact1> presents to her primary care provider with <fact2>abdominal pain</fact2>. On examination, she is found to have <fact3>rebound tenderness in the lower right quadrant of her abdomen</fact3>. Further workup suggests <fact4>ovarian cancer</fact4>, which is confirmed later in the week to be <fact5>stage 4 with confirmed distant metastases in the lungs and brain</fact5>. Which of the following routes describes the most likely lymphatic route for this malignancy to have metastasized to the brain?

A) Sentinel node - left lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - right bronchomediastinal trunk - right lymphatic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
B) Sentinel node - left lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - left subclavian vein - systemic circulation
C) Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - right bronchomediastinal trunk - right lymphatic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
D) Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - right subclavian vein - systemic circulation
E) Sentinel node - right lumbar trunk - cisterna chyli - thoracic duct - left subclavian vein - systemic circulation

Answer: Given the patient's <fact4>ovarian cancer</fact4> with <fact5>distant metastases in the lungs and brain</fact5>, the cancer cells would need to travel from the pelvic area to the brain via the lymphatic system. The lymphatic drainage from the ovaries typically goes to the lumbar trunks, then to the cisterna chyli, and finally to the thoracic duct. From the thoracic duct, the lymphatic fluid drains into the systemic circulation through the left subclavian vein. Since the metastases are in the brain, which is supplied by the systemic circulation, the most likely route would be the one that involves the thoracic duct and the left subclavian vein. Therefore, the correct answer is {B}.

question:
A 42-year-old man presents to a neurologist for evaluation of severe headache. He started experiencing episodic headaches and palpitations 3 months ago; however, he thought that these symptoms were simply related to the stress of moving and starting a new job. He has continued to experience these intermittent headaches and has also noticed that he sweats profusely during these episodes. On presentation his temperature is 99.1°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 163/112 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 15/min. Physical exam reveals pallor and perspiration but is otherwise unremarkable. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is produced by cells located in which region of the histology slide shown in figure A?
A) A
B) B
C) C
D) D
E) E
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>42-year-old man</fact1> presents to a neurologist for evaluation of <fact2>severe headache</fact2>. He started experiencing <fact3>episodic headaches and palpitations</fact3> <fact4>3 months ago</fact4>; however, he thought that these symptoms were simply related to the stress of moving and starting a new job. He has continued to experience these <fact5>intermittent headaches</fact5> and has also noticed that he <fact6>sweats profusely during these episodes</fact6>. On presentation his <fact7>temperature is 99.1°F (37.3°C)</fact7>, <fact8>blood pressure is 163/112 mmHg</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 112/min</fact9>, and <fact10>respirations are 15/min</fact10>. Physical exam reveals <fact11>pallor and perspiration</fact11> but is otherwise unremarkable. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is produced by cells located in which region of the histology slide shown in figure A?

Answer: 
Analyzing the <fact1>42-year-old man's</fact1> symptoms, including <fact2>severe headache</fact2>, <fact3>episodic headaches and palpitations</fact3>, <fact5>intermittent headaches</fact5>, and <fact6>excessive sweating</fact6>, along with his elevated <fact8>blood pressure of 163/112 mmHg</fact8>, <fact9>increased pulse of 112/min</fact9>, and <fact11>physical exam findings of pallor and perspiration</fact11>, suggests a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor. Pheochromocytomas arise from the adrenal medulla, which is composed of chromaffin cells. Therefore, the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is produced by cells located in the region of the adrenal medulla. The answer is {C}.

question:
A 38-year-old woman presents with eye dryness and a foreign body sensation in the eyes. On physical examination, the oral cavity shows mucosal ulceration and atrophy. Biopsy of the lower lip shows marked lymphocytic infiltration of the minor salivary glands. Which of the following is most likely seen in this patient?
A) Anti-Sjögren's syndrome type B (SS-B) antibody
B) Anti-centromere antibody
C) Anti-Jo-1 antibody
D) Anti-Scl-70 antibodies
E) Anti-double stranded (-ds)DNA
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>38-year-old woman</fact1> presents with <fact2>eye dryness and a foreign body sensation in the eyes</fact2>. On physical examination, the <fact3>oral cavity shows mucosal ulceration and atrophy</fact3>. Biopsy of the <fact4>lower lip shows marked lymphocytic infiltration of the minor salivary glands</fact4>. Which of the following is most likely seen in this patient?
A) Anti-Sjögren's syndrome type B (SS-B) antibody
B) Anti-centromere antibody
C) Anti-Jo-1 antibody
D) Anti-Scl-70 antibodies
E) Anti-double stranded (-ds)DNA

Answer: 
The patient's presentation of <fact2>eye dryness and a foreign body sensation in the eyes</fact2> along with <fact3>mucosal ulceration and atrophy in the oral cavity</fact3> and <fact4>marked lymphocytic infiltration of the minor salivary glands</fact4> on biopsy is highly suggestive of Sjögren's syndrome, an autoimmune disorder characterized by exocrine gland inflammation. The presence of lymphocytic infiltration in the minor salivary glands is a hallmark of this condition. Therefore, the most likely antibody associated with this patient's condition is the Anti-Sjögren's syndrome type B (SS-B) antibody. The answer is {A}.

question:
A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because she has a cord-like rash on her left calf that is red and painful to touch. She says that she has had multiple such lesions previously. Other medical history reveals that she has had 3 past spontaneous abortions at < 10 weeks of gestational age but has never been diagnosed with any diseases. She drinks socially but has never smoked or used drugs. She has never taken any medications except for over the counter analgesics and antipyretics. Physical exam shows that the cord-like lesion is tender, thick, and hardened on palpation. In addition, she has a lacy mottled violaceous rash on multiple extremities. Which of the following antibodies would most likely be found in this patient's blood?
A) Anti-cardiolipin
B) Anti-centromere
C) Anti-helicase
D) Anti-histone
E) Anti-ribonucleoprotein
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>32-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the emergency department because she has a <fact2>cord-like rash on her left calf that is red and painful to touch</fact2>. She says that she has had <fact3>multiple such lesions previously</fact3>. Other medical history reveals that she has had <fact4>3 past spontaneous abortions at < 10 weeks of gestational age</fact4> but has never been diagnosed with any diseases. She drinks socially but has never smoked or used drugs. She has never taken any medications except for over the counter analgesics and antipyretics. Physical exam shows that the <fact5>cord-like lesion is tender, thick, and hardened on palpation</fact5>. In addition, she has a <fact6>lacy mottled violaceous rash on multiple extremities</fact6>. Which of the following antibodies would most likely be found in this patient's blood?

Answer: 
Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>32-year-old woman</fact1> presents with a <fact2>cord-like rash on her left calf that is red and painful to touch</fact2> and has had <fact3>multiple such lesions previously</fact3>. Her medical history of <fact4>3 past spontaneous abortions at < 10 weeks of gestational age</fact4> suggests a possible underlying condition that could be contributing to these symptoms. The physical exam findings of a <fact5>cord-like lesion that is tender, thick, and hardened on palpation</fact5> and a <fact6>lacy mottled violaceous rash on multiple extremities</fact6> are indicative of livedo reticularis and are commonly associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). The presence of anti-cardiolipin antibodies is a hallmark of APS and can explain the patient's history of recurrent spontaneous abortions and thrombotic events. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
An 18-year-old patient is visiting the pediatrician with her mother for her annual exam before college starts. Her height and weight are appropriate for her age, and she is up to date on all her vaccinations and has no medical complaints. She is doing well in school and has a part-time job stocking shelves at a clothing store. She was offered a higher-paying job as a cashier at the store, but she declined. She is very shy and withdrawn with the physician. Afterwards, her mother asks to speak to the physician alone and expresses concern that her daughter is very socially isolated and feels lonely. She is also worried that her daughter is extremely sensitive to criticism, even from family. The daughter is interested in art and music, but hasn’t participated in any extracurriculars because she says that she is untalented and thinks nobody wants to hang out with her. When her mother has encouraged her to invite friends over, the daughter bursts into tears and says, “Nobody wants to be friends with me, I am too lame and ugly and I just know I’ll end up getting rejected.” Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the daughter’s behavior?
A) Schizotypal personality disorder
B) Generalized anxiety disorder
C) Avoidant personality disorder
D) Paranoid personality disorder
E) Dependent personality disorder
answer:
Reformatted Question: 

An 18-year-old patient is visiting the pediatrician with her mother for her <fact1>annual exam before college starts</fact1>. Her height and weight are appropriate for her age, and she is up to date on all her vaccinations and has no medical complaints. She is doing well in school and has a part-time job stocking shelves at a clothing store. She was offered a higher-paying job as a cashier at the store, but she declined. She is very <fact2>shy and withdrawn with the physician</fact2>. Afterwards, her mother asks to speak to the physician alone and expresses concern that her daughter is very <fact3>socially isolated and feels lonely</fact3>. She is also worried that her daughter is extremely <fact4>sensitive to criticism, even from family</fact4>. The daughter is interested in art and music, but hasn’t participated in any extracurriculars because she says that she is untalented and thinks nobody wants to hang out with her. When her mother has encouraged her to invite friends over, the daughter bursts into tears and says, “Nobody wants to be friends with me, I am too lame and ugly and I just know I’ll end up getting rejected.” Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the daughter’s behavior?

A) Schizotypal personality disorder
B) Generalized anxiety disorder
C) Avoidant personality disorder
D) Paranoid personality disorder
E) Dependent personality disorder

Answer: 

The most likely explanation for the daughter's behavior is {C} Avoidant personality disorder. This conclusion is based on several key points from the scenario: 

1. The daughter is described as being <fact2>shy and withdrawn with the physician</fact2>, indicating difficulty interacting with others, especially in new or unfamiliar situations.

2. Her mother expresses concern about the daughter's <fact3>social isolation and feelings of loneliness</fact3>, which suggests a pattern of avoidance of social interactions due to fear of rejection or criticism.

3. The daughter is extremely <fact4>sensitive to criticism, even from family</fact4>, further indicating her fear of negative judgment from others.

4. She declines opportunities for social interaction, such as the higher-paying job as a cashier, and avoids participating in extracurricular activities due to feelings of inadequacy and fear of rejection.

5. Her reaction to her mother's suggestion to invite friends over, bursting into tears and expressing negative self-statements, demonstrates a pervasive pattern of social avoidance due to feelings of inadequacy.

These behaviors and feelings are characteristic of Avoidant Personality Disorder, which is marked by pervasive feelings of social inadequacy, hypersensitivity to criticism or rejection, and social inhibition.

question:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a sudden loss of consciousness. He has asthma and has been hospitalized multiple times. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is somnolent and diaphoretic. Serum studies show a glucose concentration of 22 mg/dL and a potassium concentration of 2.4 mEq/L. A dextrose infusion is administered, after which his glucose concentration normalizes and his symptoms improve. He is admitted to the hospital for further observation. Overnight, he has another episode of decreased consciousness. Serum studies taken during the episode show a glucose concentration of 19 mg/dL, an insulin concentration of 108 mIU/L (N=2.6–24.9), and a C-peptide concentration of 0.3 ng/mL (N = 0.8–3.1). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Malingering
B) Glucagonoma
C) Primary adrenal insufficiency
D) Conversion disorder
E) Factitious disorder imposed on another
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>5-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a <fact2>sudden loss of consciousness</fact2>. He has <fact3>asthma and has been hospitalized multiple times</fact3>. His mother has <fact4>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact4>. He is <fact5>somnolent and diaphoretic</fact5>. Serum studies show a <fact6>glucose concentration of 22 mg/dL</fact6> and a <fact7>potassium concentration of 2.4 mEq/L</fact7>. A dextrose infusion is administered, after which his glucose concentration normalizes and his symptoms improve. He is admitted to the hospital for further observation. Overnight, he has another episode of <fact8>decreased consciousness</fact8>. Serum studies taken during the episode show a <fact9>glucose concentration of 19 mg/dL</fact9>, an <fact10>insulin concentration of 108 mIU/L (N=2.6–24.9)</fact10>, and a <fact11>C-peptide concentration of 0.3 ng/mL (N = 0.8–3.1)</fact11>. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Malingering
B) Glucagonoma
C) Primary adrenal insufficiency
D) Conversion disorder
E) Factitious disorder imposed on another

Answer: 
Given the patient's presentation with <fact2>sudden loss of consciousness</fact2> and <fact8>decreased consciousness</fact8> episodes, alongside low glucose concentrations (<fact6>glucose concentration of 22 mg/dL</fact6> and <fact9>glucose concentration of 19 mg/dL</fact9>), it is crucial to consider the possibility of an underlying condition causing hypoglycemia. The <fact10>insulin concentration of 108 mIU/L</fact10> is elevated, which, combined with the low glucose levels, suggests hyperinsulinemia. However, the <fact11>C-peptide concentration of 0.3 ng/mL</fact11> is low, indicating that the insulin is likely exogenous rather than endogenously produced. This discrepancy between insulin and C-peptide levels, along with the recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia, points towards the administration of exogenous insulin, which is a hallmark of factitious disorder imposed on another (previously known as Munchausen syndrome by proxy), where a caregiver (in this case, possibly the mother with <fact4>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact4>) fabricates or induces illness in a child for attention and sympathy. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is {E}.

question:
A laboratory primarily involved with studying cellular proofreading mechanisms is investigating the question of whether the ribosome can recognize a mischarged amino acid and still be incorporated into the growing peptide. In order to do so, they biochemically charge a Lys-tRNA with valine instead of lysine and insert the tRNA into the cell. They design an mRNA sequence that contains only codons for lysine. Which of the following will most likely occur?
A) The ribosome will recognize the mischarged tRNA and prevent its incorporation by removing the valine
B) The ribosome will recognize the inappropriately inserted valine residue and terminate protein translation
C) The mischarged tRNA with valine will be incorporated in the codons that specificy for lysine
D) The mischarged tRNA will be degraded by the proteasome
E) The mischarged tRNA will be removed by the lysyl-tRNA synthetase
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A laboratory primarily involved with studying cellular proofreading mechanisms is investigating the question of whether the ribosome can recognize a mischarged amino acid and still be incorporated into the growing peptide. In order to do so, they biochemically charge a <fact1>Lys-tRNA with valine instead of lysine</fact1> and insert the tRNA into the cell. They design an <fact2>mRNA sequence that contains only codons for lysine</fact2>. Which of the following will most likely occur?

Answer: 
C) The mischarged tRNA with valine will be incorporated in the codons that specify for lysine. This is because, as stated in the question, the ribosome's ability to recognize a mischarged amino acid and prevent its incorporation is being investigated, and the experimental setup involves inserting a mischarged <fact1>Lys-tRNA with valine</fact1> into the cell with an <fact2>mRNA sequence that contains only codons for lysine</fact2>. The correct answer suggests that the ribosome will not recognize the mischarged tRNA and will incorporate the valine into the growing peptide despite the codons specifying lysine.

question:
A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of back pain. For the past six days, she has had a burning pain in her upper right back and chest. She cannot recall any recent injury and has no prior history of back pain. She has a history of hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux. The patient volunteers at an animal shelter three times a week. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include ramipril and pantoprazole. The patient appears healthy and well nourished. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.42°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 145/92 mm Hg. Examination shows a long erythematous rash covered with multiple clear vesicles and crusty lesions extending from her back to below her right breast. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of the disease?
A) Viral reactivation in dorsal root ganglia
B) IgA deposits in the upper dermis
C) Bacterial lymphatic infection of the epidermis
D) Infestation with bloodsucking parasites
E) Brown recluse spider envenomation
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>70-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for the evaluation of <fact2>back pain</fact2>. For the past <fact3>six days</fact3>, she has had a <fact4>burning pain in her upper right back and chest</fact4>. She cannot recall any recent injury and has no prior history of <fact2>back pain</fact2>. She has a history of <fact5>hypertension</fact5> and <fact6>gastroesophageal reflux</fact6>. The patient volunteers at an <fact7>animal shelter</fact7> three times a week. She does not <fact8>smoke or drink alcohol</fact8>. Current medications include <fact9>ramipril</fact9> and <fact10>pantoprazole</fact10>. The patient appears healthy and well nourished. Her <fact11>temperature is 36.9°C (98.42°F)</fact11>, <fact12>pulse is 76/min</fact12>, and <fact13>blood pressure is 145/92 mm Hg</fact13>. Examination shows a <fact14>long erythematous rash covered with multiple clear vesicles and crusty lesions extending from her back to below her right breast</fact14>. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of the disease?

Answer: 
Given the patient's symptoms, specifically the <fact4>burning pain in her upper right back and chest</fact4> accompanied by a <fact14>long erythematous rash covered with multiple clear vesicles and crusty lesions</fact14>, the presentation is highly suggestive of herpes zoster, commonly known as shingles. This condition is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, which initially causes chickenpox and then remains latent in the dorsal root ganglia. Reactivation of this virus results in the characteristic rash and pain experienced by the patient. Therefore, the most likely underlying mechanism of the disease is {A} Viral reactivation in dorsal root ganglia.

question:
A 62-year-old woman with a pancreatic insulinoma is being prepared for a laparoscopic enucleation of the tumor. After induction of general anesthesia, preparation of a sterile surgical field, and port placement, the surgeon needs to enter the space posterior to the stomach to access the pancreatic tumor. Which of the following ligaments must be cut in order to access this space?
A) Phrenoesophageal ligament
B) Gastrohepatic ligament
C) Phrenicocolic ligament
D) Ligamentum venosum
E) Falciform ligament
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>62-year-old woman</fact1> with a <fact2>pancreatic insulinoma</fact2> is being prepared for a <fact3>laparoscopic enucleation of the tumor</fact3>. After <fact4>induction of general anesthesia</fact4>, <fact5>preparation of a sterile surgical field</fact5>, and <fact6>port placement</fact6>, the surgeon needs to enter the space posterior to the <fact7>stomach</fact7> to access the <fact8>pancreatic tumor</fact8>. Which of the following ligaments must be cut in order to access this space?

A) Phrenoesophageal ligament
B) Gastrohepatic ligament
C) Phrenicocolic ligament
D) Ligamentum venosum
E) Falciform ligament

Answer: The surgeon needs to access the space posterior to the <fact7>stomach</fact7> to reach the <fact8>pancreatic tumor</fact8> during the <fact3>laparoscopic enucleation</fact3>. The gastrohepatic ligament is a fibrous structure that connects the lesser omentum to the proximal portion of the duodenum and liver. It also contains the left gastric artery and vein.
