Given the patient's <fact2>four month history of fatigue and weakness</fact2>, <fact8>obese with a significant pannus</fact8>, abdominal striae, and laboratory results indicating <fact19>24-hour urinary cortisol: 470 µg (< 300 µg)</fact19> and <fact20>Serum cortisol 30 µg/mL (5-23 µg/dL)</fact20>, these findings are suggestive of Cushing's syndrome. The <fact22>48-hour high dose dexamethasone suppression trial</fact22> showing that her serum cortisol levels do not decrease, along with <fact21>low serum ACTH</fact21>, points towards an adrenal cause of Cushing's syndrome. Therefore, the best next step in management would be to visualize the adrenal glands to identify any potential tumors or hyperplasia. The answer is {A}.

question:
A 35-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency room with unilateral leg swelling. She reports that she developed painful left-sided leg swelling and redness earlier in the day. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She denies any recent prolonged travel. She experienced a similar episode affecting the opposite leg one year ago and was diagnosed with a thrombus in the right femoral vein. On examination, the left leg is erythematous and swollen. Passive dorsiflexion of the left ankle elicits pain in the left calf. Ultrasound of the leg reveals a thrombus in the left popliteal vein. A genetic workup reveals that she has an inherited condition. What is the most likely pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?
A) Elevated serum homocysteine
B) Thrombin inhibitor deficiency
C) Deficiency in protein C
D) Auto-antibodies directed against phospholipids
E) Resistance to clotting factor degradation
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>35-year-old Caucasian female</fact1> presents to the emergency room with <fact2>unilateral leg swelling</fact2>. She reports that she developed <fact3>painful left-sided leg swelling and redness earlier in the day</fact3>. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She denies any recent prolonged travel. She experienced a <fact4>similar episode affecting the opposite leg one year ago</fact4> and was diagnosed with a <fact5>thrombus in the right femoral vein</fact5>. On examination, the left leg is <fact6>erythematous and swollen</fact6>. Passive dorsiflexion of the left ankle elicits <fact7>pain in the left calf</fact7>. Ultrasound of the leg reveals a <fact8>thrombus in the left popliteal vein</fact8>. A genetic workup reveals that she has an <fact9>inherited condition</fact9>. What is the most likely pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's history of a <fact4>similar episode affecting the opposite leg one year ago</fact4> and the current presentation of a <fact8>thrombus in the left popliteal vein</fact8>, along with the fact that she has an <fact9>inherited condition</fact9>, suggests a possible genetic predisposition to thrombosis. Among the options provided, the most likely pathophysiology of this patient's condition is {E} Resistance to clotting factor degradation, which is indicative of Factor V Leiden, a common inherited condition that increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to resistance to activated protein C (APC).

question:
A 60-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of increasing difficulty in breathing with a productive cough. He reports having shortness of breath over the last 6 months, but he has felt worse since he contracted a cold that has been traveling around his office. Today, he reports body aches, headache, and fever along with this chronic cough. His past medical history is significant for prediabetes, which he controls with exercise and diet. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history. His blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse rate is 90/min, temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F), and respiratory rate is 18/min. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds bilateral, a barrel-shaped chest, and measured breathing through pursed lips. A chest X-ray reveals a flattened diaphragm and no signs of consolidation. Pulmonary function testing reveals FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%. Arterial blood gases (ABG) of this patient are most likely to reveal which of the following?
A) Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis
B) Primary respiratory acidosis
C) Primary respiratory alkalosis
D) Compensatory respiratory acidosis
E) Anion gap metabolic acidosis with respiratory alkalosis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>60-year-old man</fact1> presents with a <fact2>2-day history of increasing difficulty in breathing with a productive cough</fact2>. He reports having <fact3>shortness of breath over the last 6 months</fact3>, but he has felt worse since he contracted a <fact4>cold that has been traveling around his office</fact4>. Today, he reports <fact5>body aches, headache, and fever</fact5> along with this <fact6>chronic cough</fact6>. His past medical history is significant for <fact7>prediabetes</fact7>, which he controls with exercise and diet. He has a <fact8>30-pack-year smoking history</fact8>. His <fact9>blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg</fact9>, <fact10>pulse rate is 90/min</fact10>, <fact11>temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F)</fact11>, and <fact12>respiratory rate is 18/min</fact12>. Physical examination reveals <fact13>diminished breath sounds bilateral</fact13>, a <fact14>barrel-shaped chest</fact14>, and <fact15>measured breathing through pursed lips</fact15>. A <fact16>chest X-ray reveals a flattened diaphragm and no signs of consolidation</fact16>. <fact17>Pulmonary function testing reveals FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%</fact17>. Arterial blood gases (ABG) of this patient are most likely to reveal which of the following?

Answer: 
The patient's symptoms and test results suggest Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), characterized by <fact3>shortness of breath over the last 6 months</fact3>, <fact6>chronic cough</fact6>, <fact8>30-pack-year smoking history</fact8>, <fact13>diminished breath sounds bilateral</fact13>, <fact14>barrel-shaped chest</fact14>, and <fact15>measured breathing through pursed lips</fact15>. The <fact16>chest X-ray</fact16> showing a flattened diaphragm and the <fact17>FEV1/FVC ratio of 60%</fact17> further support this diagnosis. In COPD, patients often have chronic hypercapnia (elevated CO2 levels) due to impaired lung function, leading to a compensatory metabolic alkalosis. However, during acute exacerbations, they may experience respiratory acidosis. Therefore, the most likely ABG finding is a primary respiratory acidosis. The answer is {B}.

question:
A 61-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of abdominal pain and constipation. He reports a 4-day history of steady right lower quadrant pain. He has had one small bowel movement in 4 days. Normally he has a bowel movement once a day. His medical history is notable for poorly controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He takes enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, and atorvastatin. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history and drinks 3-4 beers per day. His diet consists primarily of fast food. His temperature is 101.8°F (38.8°C), blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 16/min. A review of the patient’s medical record reveals colonoscopy results from 1 year ago. Relevant findings included multiple small, pedunculated polyps which were removed, multiple colonic mucosal outpouchings, and no other masses. This patient’s condition is most strongly associated with which of the following disorders?
A) Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency
B) Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disorder
C) Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
D) Goodpasture syndrome
E) Menetrier disease
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>61-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care provider complaining of <fact2>abdominal pain and constipation</fact2>. He reports a <fact3>4-day history of steady right lower quadrant pain</fact3>. He has had one small bowel movement in <fact4>4 days</fact4>. Normally he has a bowel movement once a day. His medical history is notable for <fact5>poorly controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia</fact5>. He takes <fact6>enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, aspirin, and atorvastatin</fact6>. He has a <fact7>40 pack-year smoking history</fact7> and drinks <fact8>3-4 beers per day</fact8>. His diet consists primarily of <fact9>fast food</fact9>. His temperature is <fact10>101.8°F (38.8°C)</fact10>, blood pressure is <fact11>160/95 mmHg</fact11>, pulse is <fact12>90/min</fact12>, and respirations are <fact13>16/min</fact13>. A review of the patient’s medical record reveals <fact14>colonoscopy results from 1 year ago</fact14>. Relevant findings included <fact15>multiple small, pedunculated polyps which were removed</fact15>, <fact16>multiple colonic mucosal outpouchings</fact16>, and no other masses. This patient’s condition is most strongly associated with which of the following disorders?
A) Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency
B) Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disorder
C) Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
D) Goodpasture syndrome
E) Menetrier disease

Answer: The patient's presentation of <fact2>abdominal pain and constipation</fact2>, along with the findings from the <fact14>colonoscopy results from 1 year ago</fact14> showing <fact15>multiple small, pedunculated polyps</fact15> and <fact16>multiple colonic mucosal outpouchings</fact16>, is suggestive of a condition that affects the integrity of the colonic wall. Among the options provided, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a disorder that affects the body's connective tissue, leading to issues such as skin hyperextensibility, joint hypermobility, and tissue fragility. This condition is associated with gastrointestinal complications, including colonic diverticula and mucosal outpouchings, which aligns with the patient's colonoscopy findings. Therefore, the patient's condition is most strongly associated with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, option {C}.

question:
A 25-year-old male involved in a knife fight presents with a penetrating wound to the chest. The patient is unconscious and cannot provide any further history. Vitals show a temperature of 37-0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure of 85/55 mm Hg, pulse of 115/min, respirations of 19/min, and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is diaphoretic and unresponsive. Extremities are pale and cool. There is a 3-inch long penetrating wound between the 3rd and 4th intercostal space on the left side of the chest, which is bleeding profusely. Transthoracic echocardiography reveals a full thickness penetrating injury to the right ventricular free wall. There are no apparent injuries to any coronary arteries or major branches. The patient is intubated and aggressive fluid resuscitation is initiated, including a blood transfusion. Which of the following is the best definitive surgical approach to take in this patient?
A) Immediate cardiac transplant
B) Watchful waiting while resuscitative fluids are initiated
C) Interrupted 2-0 polypropylene suture with supporting pledgets
D) Needle thoracostomy over the 2nd intercostal space
E) Surgical adhesive glue
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old male</fact1> involved in a <fact2>knife fight</fact2> presents with a <fact3>penetrating wound to the chest</fact3>. The patient is <fact4>unconscious</fact4> and cannot provide any further history. Vitals show a <fact5>temperature of 37-0°C (98.6°F)</fact5>, <fact6>blood pressure of 85/55 mm Hg</fact6>, <fact7>pulse of 115/min</fact7>, <fact8>respirations of 19/min</fact8>, and <fact9>oxygen saturation of 92% on room air</fact9>. On physical examination, the patient is <fact10>diaphoretic and unresponsive</fact10>. Extremities are <fact11>pale and cool</fact11>. There is a <fact12>3-inch long penetrating wound between the 3rd and 4th intercostal space on the left side of the chest</fact12>, which is <fact13>bleeding profusely</fact13>. <fact14>Transthoracic echocardiography</fact14> reveals a <fact15>full thickness penetrating injury to the right ventricular free wall</fact15>. There are no apparent injuries to any <fact16>coronary arteries or major branches</fact16>. The patient is <fact17>intubated</fact17> and <fact18>aggressive fluid resuscitation</fact18> is initiated, including a <fact19>blood transfusion</fact19>. Which of the following is the best definitive surgical approach to take in this patient?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation with a <fact3>penetrating wound to the chest</fact3> and the findings on <fact14>transthoracic echocardiography</fact14> of a <fact15>full thickness penetrating injury to the right ventricular free wall</fact15>, the best definitive surgical approach is to repair the injury to the heart. Among the options provided, choice C, <fact20>Interrupted 2-0 polypropylene suture with supporting pledgets</fact20>, is the most appropriate method for repairing a penetrating cardiac injury, especially when there is no damage to the <fact16>coronary arteries or major branches</fact16>. This technique allows for secure closure of the wound while minimizing the risk of further damage to the surrounding tissue. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 76-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine examination. She has a history of hypertension well controlled with diet and exercise. She has no history of smoking or illicit drug use. She walks one mile daily. Her pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 119/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. When compared to a healthy 20-year-old woman, which of the following changes in respiratory function is most likely present in this patient?
A) Increased lung compliance
B) Increased vital capacity
C) Decreased residual volume
D) Increased chest wall compliance
E) Decreased A-a gradient
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>76-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for a routine examination. She has a history of <fact2>hypertension well controlled with diet and exercise</fact2>. She has <fact3>no history of smoking or illicit drug use</fact3>. She <fact4>walks one mile daily</fact4>. Her <fact5>pulse is 68/min</fact5>, <fact6>respirations are 16/min</fact6>, and <fact7>blood pressure is 119/76 mm Hg</fact7>. Physical examination shows <fact8>no abnormalities</fact8>. When compared to a healthy <fact9>20-year-old woman</fact9>, which of the following changes in respiratory function is most likely present in this patient?

Answer: 
When comparing the respiratory function of the <fact1>76-year-old woman</fact1> to a healthy <fact9>20-year-old woman</fact9>, it is essential to consider the natural aging process and its effects on the respiratory system. Despite the <fact1>76-year-old woman's</fact1> healthy lifestyle, including <fact4>walking one mile daily</fact4> and having <fact2>hypertension well controlled with diet and exercise</fact2>, age-related changes in lung function are inevitable. Among the options provided, the most likely change in respiratory function present in this patient is a decreased A-a gradient. However, this option is not correct, as the A-a gradient typically increases with age due to decreased efficiency in gas exchange. 

The correct answer is actually related to the changes in lung volumes and capacities that occur with aging. As people age, their lung compliance decreases, and their chest wall compliance also decreases. However, the most notable change is the decrease in vital capacity and the increase in residual volume. Among the provided options, none directly state "decreased vital capacity" or "increased residual volume," but we can infer the correct answer based on the process of elimination.

Given the options, the best answer is C) Decreased residual volume. This option might seem counterintuitive, as residual volume typically increases with age. However, considering the provided options and the fact that the question asks for the most likely change present in this patient compared to a healthy <fact9>20-year-old woman</fact9>, the correct answer is indeed C) Decreased residual volume, but with the understanding that this is in comparison to the expected increase in residual volume in older adults.

question:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, breast tenderness, increased urinary frequency, and intermittent nausea for 2 weeks. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. She has a history of a seizure disorder treated with carbamazepine. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is positive. The child is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
A) Renal dysplasia
B) Meningocele
C) Teeth discoloration
D) Sensorineural hearing loss
E) Vaginal clear cell carcinoma
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>32-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>fatigue, breast tenderness, increased urinary frequency, and intermittent nausea</fact2> for <fact3>2 weeks</fact3>. Her <fact4>last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago</fact4>. She has a <fact5>history of a seizure disorder treated with carbamazepine</fact5>. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A <fact6>urine pregnancy test is positive</fact6>. The child is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>32-year-old woman's</fact1> <fact5>history of a seizure disorder treated with carbamazepine</fact5> and the positive <fact6>urine pregnancy test</fact6>, the child is at increased risk for congenital malformations due to the teratogenic effects of carbamazepine. Among the provided options, neural tube defects such as <fact7>meningocele</fact7> are associated with carbamazepine use during pregnancy. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 24-year-old man with chronic back pain comes to the physician to establish care after moving to Florida. He complains of anxiety, nausea, abdominal cramping, vomiting, and diarrhea for three days. He denies smoking, drinking alcohol, and using illicit drugs. He appears restless. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 150/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dilated pupils, diaphoresis, and piloerection. His abdominal exam shows diffuse mild tenderness. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding. His hemoglobin concentration is 14.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8,000/mm, and platelet count is 250,000/mm3; serum studies and urinalysis show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
A) Lorazepam
B) Naltrexone
C) Methadone
D) Morphine
E) Naloxone
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>24-year-old man</fact1> with <fact2>chronic back pain</fact2> comes to the physician to establish care after moving to Florida. He complains of <fact3>anxiety, nausea, abdominal cramping, vomiting, and diarrhea</fact3> for three days. He denies <fact4>smoking, drinking alcohol, and using illicit drugs</fact4>. He appears <fact5>restless</fact5>. His <fact6>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact6>, <fact7>pulse is 110/min</fact7>, and <fact8>blood pressure is 150/86 mm Hg</fact8>. Physical examination shows <fact9>dilated pupils, diaphoresis, and piloerection</fact9>. His <fact10>abdominal exam shows diffuse mild tenderness</fact10>. There is no <fact11>rebound tenderness or guarding</fact11>. His <fact12>hemoglobin concentration is 14.5 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8,000/mm, and platelet count is 250,000/mm3</fact12>; <fact13>serum studies and urinalysis show no abnormalities</fact13>. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact3>anxiety, nausea, abdominal cramping, vomiting, and diarrhea</fact3> along with physical examination findings of <fact9>dilated pupils, diaphoresis, and piloerection</fact9>, and the absence of <fact11>rebound tenderness or guarding</fact11> and normal <fact12>hemoglobin concentration, leukocyte count, and platelet count</fact12> as well as <fact13>normal serum studies and urinalysis</fact13>, the clinical picture suggests opioid withdrawal. Given the patient's <fact2>chronic back pain</fact2> and the presence of withdrawal symptoms, the most appropriate pharmacotherapy would be to manage the withdrawal symptoms and potentially transition the patient to a safer, longer-acting opioid for pain management. Among the options provided, Methadone is a long-acting opioid agonist used for opioid maintenance therapy and can help manage withdrawal symptoms. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 35-year-old man visits your office for his annual health checkup. He was diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder 6 months ago, which is being treated with citalopram. He comments that his symptoms have improved since initiating the prescribed therapy; however, in the past 2 months, he has been unable to have sexual intercourse due to weak tumescence and low libido. His blood pressure is 122/74 mm Hg, heart rate is 75/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. Physical examination reveals regular heart and lung sounds. What is the appropriate step in the management of this patient?
A) Lowering citalopram dose
B) Addition of bupropion
C) Switch to fluoxetine
D) Addition of sildenafil
E) Switch to selegiline
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>35-year-old man</fact1> visits your office for his annual health checkup. He was diagnosed with <fact2>generalized anxiety disorder</fact2> 6 months ago, which is being treated with <fact3>citalopram</fact3>. He comments that his symptoms have improved since initiating the prescribed therapy; however, in the past <fact4>2 months</fact4>, he has been unable to have sexual intercourse due to <fact5>weak tumescence and low libido</fact5>. His <fact6>blood pressure is 122/74 mm Hg</fact6>, <fact7>heart rate is 75/min</fact7>, and <fact8>respiratory rate is 16/min</fact8>. Physical examination reveals <fact9>regular heart and lung sounds</fact9>. What is the appropriate step in the management of this patient?

Answer: Considering the patient's <fact2>generalized anxiety disorder</fact2> is being treated with <fact3>citalopram</fact3> and his symptoms have improved, but he has developed <fact5>weak tumescence and low libido</fact5> in the past <fact4>2 months</fact4>, it is essential to address the sexual side effects of the medication. Lowering the dose of citalopram (option A) may not be the best approach as it could compromise the management of his anxiety disorder. Switching to fluoxetine (option C) or selegiline (option E) might not necessarily resolve the sexual side effects. The addition of sildenafil (option D) could be helpful in addressing the patient's erectile dysfunction but does not address the underlying cause. The addition of bupropion (option B) is often used to counteract the sexual side effects of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like citalopram, making it the most appropriate step in the management of this patient.

question:
A 63-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for follow-up. He reports a slow and steady weight gain of 6 pounds over the past 6 months, despite attempts to control his diet and increase his level of exercise. His medications include pravastatin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. On exam, his vital signs are stable. He is obese (BMI 32), and his waist circumference is 43 inches. His physician is concerned about an abnormal fasting blood glucose and dyslipidemia. On further work-up with oral glucose tolerance test, the patient is diagnosed with diabetes. Which of the following associations is consistent with this patient’s most likely form of diabetes?
A) Strong HLA class II gene makeup
B) Pancreatic islet cell amyloid deposition
C) Pancreatic islet cell leukocyte infiltration
D) Auto-antibodies against pancreatic islet cell antigens
E) Unrelated to his abdominal obesity
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>63-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care physician for follow-up. He reports a <fact2>slow and steady weight gain of 6 pounds over the past 6 months</fact2>, despite attempts to control his diet and increase his level of exercise. His medications include <fact3>pravastatin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide</fact3>. On exam, his vital signs are stable. He is <fact4>obese (BMI 32)</fact4>, and his <fact5>wrist circumference is 43 inches</fact5>. His physician is concerned about an abnormal fasting blood glucose and dyslipidemia. On further work-up with oral glucose tolerance test, the patient is diagnosed with diabetes. Which of the following associations is consistent with this patient’s most likely form of diabetes?
A) Strong HLA class II gene makeup
B) Pancreatic islet cell amyloid deposition
C) Pancreatic islet cell leukocyte infiltration
D) Auto-antibodies against pancreatic islet cell antigens
E) Unrelated to his abdominal obesity

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, including <fact2>slow and steady weight gain</fact2>, <fact4>obesity (BMI 32)</fact4>, and <fact5>waist circumference of 43 inches</fact5>, along with the development of abnormal fasting blood glucose and dyslipidemia, it is likely that the patient has type 2 diabetes. Among the options provided, choice B, <fact6>Pancreatic islet cell amyloid deposition</fact6>, is a characteristic feature of type 2 diabetes. This condition involves the deposition of amyloid in the pancreatic islets, which can lead to impaired insulin secretion and contribute to the development of diabetes. Therefore, the correct answer is {B}.

question:
Patients with the diagnosis of sickle cell anemia make a specific type of hemoglobin known as HgbS. This mutation results in the sickling of their red blood cells when exposed to inciting factors such as hypoxic conditions. Patients are often treated with hydroxyurea, which has which of the following direct effects on their hemoglobin physiology?
A) Increases oxygen carrying capacity of hemoglobin
B) Decreases oxygen carrying capacity of hemoglobin
C) Increases levels of fetal hemoglobin (HgbF)
D) Decreases levels of HgbS
E) Decreases levels of fetal hemoglobin (HgbF)
answer:
Reformatted Question: A patient with the diagnosis of <fact1>sickle cell anemia</fact1> makes a specific type of hemoglobin known as <fact2>HgbS</fact2>. This <fact3>mutation</fact3> results in the <fact4>sickling of their red blood cells</fact4> when exposed to inciting factors such as <fact5>hypoxic conditions</fact5>. Patients are often treated with <fact6>hydroxyurea</fact6>, which has which of the following direct effects on their hemoglobin physiology?

Answer: C) Increases levels of fetal hemoglobin (HgbF)

Explanation: The question asks about the direct effect of <fact6>hydroxyurea</fact6> on the hemoglobin physiology of patients with <fact1>sickle cell anemia</fact1>. Hydroxyurea is known to increase the levels of <fact7>fetal hemoglobin (HgbF)</fact7>, which is beneficial for patients with sickle cell anemia as it can help reduce the severity of the disease by decreasing the amount of <fact2>HgbS</fact2> in the blood. This is because HgbF is less likely to undergo <fact4>sickling</fact4> when exposed to <fact5>hypoxic conditions</fact5>, thereby reducing the risk of complications associated with sickle cell anemia.

question:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of persistent bleeding from his nose over the past hour. The bleeding started spontaneously. He has no history of a similar episode. He takes no medications. There is no history of abnormal bleeding in the family. His vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, he is pressing a gauze against his left nostril while hyperextending his head. The gauze is stained with blood and upon withdrawal of the gauze blood slowly drips out of his left nostrils. There is no bleeding from the right nostril. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy?
A) Anterior packing and topical antibiotics
B) Oxymetazoline nasal spray
C) Placement of an epinephrine gauze in the left nostril
D) Silver nitrate cauterization of the bleeding vessel and surrounding vessels
E) Squeezing the nostrils manually for 10 minutes with the head elevated
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>12-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of <fact2>persistent bleeding from his nose over the past hour</fact2>. The bleeding started <fact3>spontaneously</fact3>. He has no history of a similar episode. He takes no medications. There is no history of <fact4>abnormal bleeding in the family</fact4>. His vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, he is pressing a gauze against his left nostril while hyperextending his head. The gauze is stained with blood and upon withdrawal of the gauze <fact5>blood slowly drips out of his left nostrils</fact5>. There is no bleeding from the right nostril. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy?

Answer: Given the <fact1>12-year-old boy's</fact1> presentation with <fact2>persistent bleeding from his nose</fact2> that started <fact3>spontaneously</fact3> and the absence of any <fact4>abnormal bleeding in the family</fact4>, the initial approach should focus on controlling the bleeding. The fact that <fact5>blood slowly drips out of his left nostrils</fact5> suggests a need for a simple, non-invasive method to stop the bleeding. Among the options provided, squeezing the nostrils manually for 10 minutes with the head elevated is a first-line, non-invasive technique that can effectively control anterior nasal bleeding. Therefore, the most appropriate initial therapy is {E}.

question:
A 23-year-old man presents with swelling of the left knee. He noticed the swelling a day ago while preparing for the college basketball game. He has had approximately 10 different sexual partners in the past 3 months. Synovial fluid tap shows a WBC count of 90,000 cells/mm3. What is the mechanism of action of the drug which is indicated for the treatment of this patient’s most likely condition?
A) Metabolic inhibitor
B) Cell wall inhibitor
C) Neutrophil migration inhibitor
D) Prostaglandin inhibitor
E) Uric acid synthesis inhibitor
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>23-year-old man</fact1> presents with <fact2>swelling of the left knee</fact2>. He noticed the <fact2>swelling</fact2> a day ago while preparing for the college basketball game. He has had approximately <fact3>10 different sexual partners</fact3> in the past <fact4>3 months</fact4>. <fact5>Synovial fluid tap</fact5> shows a <fact6>WBC count of 90,000 cells/mm3</fact6>. What is the mechanism of action of the drug which is indicated for the treatment of this patient’s most likely condition?

Answer: 
Given the patient's presentation of <fact2>swelling of the left knee</fact2> with a high <fact6>WBC count of 90,000 cells/mm3</fact6> in the <fact5>synovial fluid tap</fact5>, along with a history of multiple sexual partners (<fact3>10 different sexual partners</fact3> in the past <fact4>3 months</fact4>), the most likely condition is septic arthritis, possibly due to a sexually transmitted infection such as gonorrhea or chlamydia. The treatment for septic arthritis typically involves antibiotics. The mechanism of action of the drug indicated for the treatment of this condition would most likely be a <fact7>cell wall inhibitor</fact7>, as antibiotics targeting bacterial cell wall synthesis (e.g., penicillin or cephalosporins) are effective against a wide range of bacteria, including those causing septic arthritis. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 27-year-old female presents to her physician with a palpable thyroid nodule. Iodine uptake testing shows that the nodule has decreased iodine uptake compared with the rest of the thyroid gland. A fine-needle aspiration is performed and the physician calls telling the patient that she has a neoplasm of the thyroid. Which of the following diagnoses is the most likely?
A) Papillary carcinoma
B) Medullary carcinoma
C) Follicular carcinoma
D) Anaplastic carcinoma
E) Hurthle cell carcinoma
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>27-year-old female</fact1> presents to her physician with a <fact2>palpable thyroid nodule</fact2>. <fact3>Iodine uptake testing</fact3> shows that the nodule has <fact4>decreased iodine uptake</fact4> compared with the rest of the thyroid gland. A <fact5>fine-needle aspiration</fact5> is performed and the physician calls telling the patient that she has a <fact6>neoplasm of the thyroid</fact6>. Which of the following diagnoses is the most likely?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with a <fact2>palpable thyroid nodule</fact2> and the results of the <fact3>iodine uptake testing</fact3> showing <fact4>decreased iodine uptake</fact4>, this suggests that the nodule is not functioning normally, which is often seen in thyroid cancers. The <fact5>fine-needle aspiration</fact5> confirmed the presence of a <fact6>neoplasm of the thyroid</fact6>. Among the options provided, {C} Follicular carcinoma is the most likely diagnosis because it is a type of thyroid cancer that typically presents as a solitary nodule with decreased iodine uptake.

question:
A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain and vomiting for 8 hours. He has had around 3–4 episodes of greenish colored vomit during this period. He has major depressive disorder with psychosis. His mother has Graves' disease. Current medications include sertraline and haloperidol. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. He is diagnosed with acute appendicitis and is taken to the operating room for an emergency laparoscopic appendectomy. The appendix is gangrenous and perforated with purulent fluid in the pelvis. Just after the appendiceal base is ligated, the patient shows muscle rigidity and profuse diaphoresis. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 146/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The end-tidal CO2 is 85 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
A) Propranolol
B) Dantrolene
C) Bromocriptine
D) Cyproheptadine
E) Surgical embolectomy
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>15-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the emergency department because of <fact2>severe abdominal pain and vomiting</fact2> for 8 hours. He has had around 3–4 episodes of <fact3>greenish colored vomit</fact3> during this period. He has <fact4>major depressive disorder with psychosis</fact4>. His mother has <fact5>Graves' disease</fact5>. Current medications include <fact6>sertraline and haloperidol</fact6>. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. He is diagnosed with <fact7>acute appendicitis</fact7> and is taken to the operating room for an emergency laparoscopic appendectomy. The appendix is <fact8>gangrenous and perforated with purulent fluid in the pelvis</fact8>. Just after the appendiceal base is ligated, the patient shows <fact9>muscle rigidity and profuse diaphoresis</fact9>. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 146/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The <fact10>end-tidal CO2 is 85 mm Hg</fact10>. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?

Answer: Given the patient's symptoms of <fact9>muscle rigidity and profuse diaphoresis</fact9> immediately after the surgical procedure, along with a high <fact10>end-tidal CO2 of 85 mm Hg</fact10>, this presentation is highly suggestive of malignant hyperthermia (MH), a life-threatening medical emergency. MH is often triggered by certain anesthetics and can be exacerbated by stressors such as surgery. Considering the patient's current state and the need for immediate intervention to prevent further complications or death, the most appropriate treatment is Dantrolene, a specific antidote for malignant hyperthermia. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 47-year-old woman seeks evaluation at your office because she has had postcoital vaginal bleeding for the past 8 months with occasional intermenstrual watery, blood-tinged vaginal discharge. Her family history is negative for malignancies and inherited disorders. She is the result of a pregnancy complicated by numerous miscarriages in the 1960s, for which her mother received diethylstilbestrol. During a pelvic examination, you notice a polypoid mass on the anterior wall of the vagina. The bimanual examination is negative for adnexal masses. You suspect the presence of carcinoma and, therefore, send tissue samples to pathology, which confirmed the presence of malignant cells. Which of the following is the most likely malignant tumor in this patient?
A) Clear cell adenocarcinoma
B) Melanoma
C) Botryoid sarcoma
D) Verrucous carcinoma
E) Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>47-year-old woman</fact1> seeks evaluation at your office because she has had <fact2>postcoital vaginal bleeding</fact2> for the past <fact3>8 months</fact3> with occasional <fact4>intermenstrual watery, blood-tinged vaginal discharge</fact4>. Her <fact5>family history is negative for malignancies and inherited disorders</fact5>. She is the result of a pregnancy complicated by numerous <fact6>miscarriages in the 1960s</fact6>, for which her mother received <fact7>diethylstilbestrol</fact7>. During a <fact8>pelvic examination</fact8>, you notice a <fact9>polypoid mass on the anterior wall of the vagina</fact9>. The <fact10>bimanual examination is negative for adnexal masses</fact10>. You suspect the presence of carcinoma and, therefore, send tissue samples to pathology, which confirmed the presence of malignant cells. Which of the following is the most likely malignant tumor in this patient?
A) Clear cell adenocarcinoma
B) Melanoma
C) Botryoid sarcoma
D) Verrucous carcinoma
E) Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

Answer: 
The patient's symptoms of <fact2>postcoital vaginal bleeding</fact2> and <fact4>intermenstrual watery, blood-tinged vaginal discharge</fact4> for <fact3>8 months</fact3> along with the finding of a <fact9>polypoid mass on the anterior wall of the vagina</fact9> during the <fact8>pelvic examination</fact8> suggest a vaginal malignancy. Given her history of being exposed to <fact7>diethylstilbestrol</fact7> in utero due to her mother's complications with <fact6>miscarriages in the 1960s</fact6>, the most likely malignant tumor is clear cell adenocarcinoma, which is a known risk associated with in utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent skin lesions. The episodes of lesions started at the age of 2 months and multiple treatment options have been attempted without success. He has also had several episodes of respiratory tract infections, enlarged lymph nodes, and recurrent fevers since birth. The boy attends daycare. His older brother has asthma. The patient's immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 5th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. He appears ill. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows several raised, erythematous lesions of different sizes over the face, neck, groins, and extremities; some secrete pus. Cervical and axillary lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Chronic granulomatous disease
B) Ataxia-telangiectasia
C) Atopic dermatitis
D) Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome
E) Chediak-Higashi syndrome
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>3-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the physician for the evaluation of <fact2>recurrent skin lesions</fact2>. The episodes of lesions started at the age of <fact3>2 months</fact3> and multiple treatment options have been attempted without success. He has also had several episodes of <fact4>respiratory tract infections</fact4>, <fact5>enlarged lymph nodes</fact5>, and <fact6>recurrent fevers</fact6> since birth. The boy attends daycare. His older brother has asthma. The patient's immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the <fact7>5th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight</fact7>. He appears ill. His temperature is <fact8>38°C (100.4°F)</fact8>, pulse is <fact9>100/min</fact9>, and blood pressure is <fact10>100/60 mm Hg</fact10>. Examination shows several <fact11>raised, erythematous lesions of different sizes over the face, neck, groins, and extremities; some secrete pus</fact11>. Cervical and axillary lymph nodes are <fact12>enlarged bilaterally</fact12>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Chronic granulomatous disease
B) Ataxia-telangiectasia
C) Atopic dermatitis
D) Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome
E) Chediak-Higashi syndrome

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>3-year-old boy's</fact1> history of <fact2>recurrent skin lesions</fact2> that started at the age of <fact3>2 months</fact3>, along with <fact4>respiratory tract infections</fact4>, <fact5>enlarged lymph nodes</fact5>, and <fact6>recurrent fevers</fact6> since birth, it is indicative of an underlying immunodeficiency. The presence of <fact11>raised, erythematous lesions</fact11> that secrete pus and <fact12>enlarged lymph nodes</fact12> suggests a condition characterized by impaired neutrophil function. Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is a condition that affects the body's ability to kill certain bacteria and fungi, leading to recurrent life-threatening infections, which aligns with the patient's symptoms. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is {A}.

question:
A 78-year-old woman presents to the office for an annual health check-up with her family physician accompanied by her daughter. She has no complaints during this visit but her daughter states that she is having difficulty locating objects such as the television remote, car keys, and her purse. Her medical history is significant for Alzheimer’s dementia, coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, congestive heart failure, osteoarthritis and centrilobular emphysema. The patient takes memantine, atorvastatin, metformin, levothyroxine, lisinopril, aspirin, albuterol, and ipratropium. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits today. Physical exam reveals an elderly female in no acute distress, oriented to person, place and year, but not to month or day of the week. She has a 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border along with an S3 gallop. There are mild crackles at the lung bases. The remainder of the exam is normal. A previous urine culture reports growth of > 100,000 CFU of Enterobacter. Urinalysis findings are offered below:
Leukocyte esterase  positive
WBCs 50-100 cell/HPF
Nitrites positive
RBCs 2 cell/HPF
Epithelial cells 2 cell/HPF
Urine pH 5.7
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
A) TMP-SMX
B) Nitrofurantoin
C) Levofloxacin
D) Cephalexin
E) No treatment is necessary
answer:
Reformatted Question: 

A <fact1>78-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the office for an annual health check-up with her family physician accompanied by her daughter. She has no complaints during this visit but her daughter states that she is having difficulty locating objects such as the <fact2>television remote, car keys, and her purse</fact2>. Her medical history is significant for <fact3>Alzheimer’s dementia, coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, congestive heart failure, osteoarthritis and centrilobular emphysema</fact3>. The patient takes <fact4>memantine, atorvastatin, metformin, levothyroxine, lisinopril, aspirin, albuterol, and ipratropium</fact4>. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits today. Physical exam reveals an elderly female in no acute distress, oriented to person, place and year, but not to month or day of the week. She has a <fact5>3/6 holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border along with an S3 gallop</fact5>. There are mild crackles at the lung bases. The remainder of the exam is normal. A previous <fact6>urine culture reports growth of > 100,000 CFU of Enterobacter</fact6>. Urinalysis findings are offered below:
<fact7>Leukocyte esterase  positive</fact7>
<fact8>WBCs 50-100 cell/HPF</fact8>
<fact9>Nitrites positive</fact9>
<fact10>RBCs 2 cell/HPF</fact10>
<fact11>Epithelial cells 2 cell/HPF</fact11>
<fact12>Urine pH 5.7</fact12>
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
A) TMP-SMX
B) Nitrofurantoin
C) Levofloxacin
D) Cephalexin
E) No treatment is necessary

Answer: Considering the patient's <fact6>urine culture reports growth of > 100,000 CFU of Enterobacter</fact6> and urinalysis findings, including <fact7>positive leukocyte esterase</fact7>, <fact8>WBCs 50-100 cell/HPF</fact8>, and <fact9>positive nitrites</fact9>, these results are indicative of a urinary tract infection (UTI). Given the patient's <fact3>medical history</fact3> and the presence of <fact5>congestive heart failure</fact5>, it is essential to choose an antibiotic that is effective against Enterobacter and safe for the patient. Nitrofurantoin is generally not effective against Enterobacter. TMP-SMX and Levofloxacin are options, but the patient's <fact4>medication list</fact4> does not indicate any contraindications to Cephalexin, which is effective against Enterobacter. However, the patient's <fact3>medical history</fact3> of <fact3>Alzheimer’s dementia</fact3> and the potential for Cephalexin to cause confusion as a side effect should be considered. Despite this, Cephalexin is likely the best option among those listed for treating the UTI caused by Enterobacter. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
Three days after induction chemotherapy, a 9-year-old boy is admitted to the hospital for fever and neutropenia. He was initially diagnosed with t(9;22)-positive acute T cell lymphoblastic leukemia following workup for fatigue and pancytopenia. He is fully conscious. His blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), pulse is 98/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical examination including examination of the central venous catheter site shows no source of infection. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated. Which of the following factors about this patient most strongly indicates a poor prognosis?
A) Age
B) Cytogenetics
C) Fever and neutropenia
D) Initial presentation
E) Immunological subtype
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>9-year-old boy</fact1> is admitted to the hospital for <fact2>fever and neutropenia</fact2> three days after induction chemotherapy. He was initially diagnosed with <fact3>t(9;22)-positive acute T cell lymphoblastic leukemia</fact3> following workup for <fact4>fatigue and pancytopenia</fact4>. His vital signs are stable with a <fact5>blood pressure of 110/65 mm Hg</fact5>, <fact6>temperature of 39.5°C (103.1°F)</fact6>, <fact7>pulse of 98/min</fact7>, and <fact8>respiratory rate of 14/min</fact8>. Physical examination including examination of the central venous catheter site shows <fact9>no source of infection</fact9>. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated. Which of the following factors about this patient most strongly indicates a poor prognosis?
A) Age
B) Cytogenetics
C) Fever and neutropenia
D) Initial presentation
E) Immunological subtype

Answer: 
Considering the provided information, the factor that most strongly indicates a poor prognosis in this patient is his <fact3>t(9;22)-positive acute T cell lymphoblastic leukemia</fact3>. The t(9;22) translocation, also known as the Philadelphia chromosome, is commonly associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) but can also occur in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). In the context of ALL, the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome is generally considered a high-risk feature and is associated with a poorer prognosis compared to other cytogenetic abnormalities. Therefore, the correct answer is {B}.

question:
A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department. He was found unconscious on the street. The staff recognizes him as a local homeless man with a long history of alcoholism. At the hospital, his pulse is 95/min, the blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, the respirations are 20/min, and the oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, the unconscious man is covered in bloody vomit with small clots and food particles. He smells of alcohol. A digital exam reveals black tarry stool in the rectal vault. The patient is given oxygen, IV fluids, and an NG-tube is placed and set to intermittent suction. Labs are sent and the patient is prepared for a procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in his management?
A) Undergo colonoscopy
B) Undergo upper GI endoscopy
C) Selective mesenteric angiography
D) Proton pump inhibitors with anti-H.pylori regimen
E) Surgery for peptic ulcer disease
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>56-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department. He was found <fact2>unconscious on the street</fact2>. The staff recognizes him as a local <fact3>homeless man with a long history of alcoholism</fact3>. At the hospital, his <fact4>pulse is 95/min</fact4>, the <fact5>blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg</fact5>, the <fact6>respirations are 20/min</fact6>, and the <fact7>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact7>. On physical exam, the <fact8>unconscious man is covered in bloody vomit with small clots and food particles</fact8>. He <fact9>smells of alcohol</fact9>. A digital exam reveals <fact10>black tarry stool in the rectal vault</fact10>. The patient is given <fact11>oxygen, IV fluids, and an NG-tube is placed and set to intermittent suction</fact11>. Labs are sent and the patient is prepared for a procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in his management?

Answer: Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>56-year-old man</fact1> was found <fact2>unconscious on the street</fact2> with a history of <fact3>alcoholism</fact3>, and upon examination, he was found to be <fact8>covered in bloody vomit with small clots and food particles</fact8> and had <fact10>black tarry stool in the rectal vault</fact10>. These findings are indicative of upper gastrointestinal bleeding, likely due to a peptic ulcer. The patient has already been given <fact11>oxygen, IV fluids, and an NG-tube is placed and set to intermittent suction</fact11>, which are appropriate initial steps. The next step in management would be to directly visualize the upper GI tract to identify and potentially treat the source of bleeding. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in his management is {B}.

Note: Option B, "Undergo upper GI endoscopy," is the correct answer because it directly addresses the likely source of the patient's symptoms, which is upper gastrointestinal bleeding.

question:
A 9-year-old boy is brought in by his mother because of bruising on his torso and limbs. The patient’s mother denies any other symptoms and says he is otherwise healthy. Physical examination shows multiple petechiae and bruising on the torso and extremities bilaterally. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. A complete blood count is normal. His coagulation profile reveals:
Prothrombin time (PT) 12 sec
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 60 sec
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
B) Hemophilia B
C) Immune thrombocytopenic purpura
D) Von Willebrand disease
E) Hemophilia A
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>9-year-old boy</fact1> is brought in by his mother because of <fact2>bruising on his torso and limbs</fact2>. The patient’s mother denies any other symptoms and says he is otherwise healthy. Physical examination shows <fact3>multiple petechiae and bruising on the torso and extremities bilaterally</fact3>. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. A complete blood count is normal. His coagulation profile reveals:
<fact4>Prothrombin time (PT) 12 sec</fact4>
<fact5>Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 60 sec</fact5>
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Answer: 
The patient presents with <fact2>bruising on his torso and limbs</fact2> and physical examination shows <fact3>multiple petechiae and bruising on the torso and extremities bilaterally</fact3>, indicating a bleeding disorder. The complete blood count is normal, which rules out conditions like thrombocytopenia (C). The coagulation profile reveals a normal <fact4>prothrombin time (PT) of 12 sec</fact4> but a prolonged <fact5>activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) of 60 sec</fact5>, suggesting a problem with the intrinsic coagulation pathway. This is consistent with Hemophilia A (E), a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency in factor VIII, which is part of the intrinsic pathway. Hemophilia B (B) is caused by a deficiency in factor IX, also part of the intrinsic pathway, but it is less common than Hemophilia A. Von Willebrand disease (D) is a disorder of primary hemostasis, not the intrinsic pathway, and typically presents with a normal aPTT. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (A) is a type of cancer that can cause bleeding due to thrombocytopenia, but the patient's complete blood count is normal. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is Hemophilia A (E).

question:
A 7-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his mother. She reports that the child develops severe sunburns every time the infant is exposed to sunlight. She has applied copious amounts of sunscreen to the infant but this has not helped the problem. On examination, there are multiple areas of reddened skin primarily in sun exposed areas. The child’s corneas appear irritated and erythematous. Which of the following processes is likely impaired in this patient?
A) Nucleotide excision repair
B) Non-homologous end joining
C) Homologous recombination
D) Mismatch repair
E) Base excision repair
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>7-month-old male infant</fact1> is brought to the pediatrician by his mother. She reports that the child develops <fact2>severe sunburns every time the infant is exposed to sunlight</fact2>. She has applied <fact3>copious amounts of sunscreen to the infant</fact3> but this has not helped the problem. On examination, there are <fact4>multiple areas of reddened skin primarily in sun exposed areas</fact4>. The child’s <fact5>corneas appear irritated and erythematous</fact5>. Which of the following processes is likely impaired in this patient?

Answer: Considering the <fact1>7-month-old male infant</fact1> develops <fact2>severe sunburns every time the infant is exposed to sunlight</fact2> despite the application of <fact3>copious amounts of sunscreen</fact3>, and the presence of <fact4>multiple areas of reddened skin primarily in sun exposed areas</fact4> along with <fact5>irritated and erythematous corneas</fact5>, it suggests an underlying condition that affects the body's ability to repair DNA damage caused by ultraviolet (UV) light. The process most likely impaired in this patient is nucleotide excision repair (NER), which is responsible for repairing UV-induced DNA damage. This condition is characteristic of xeroderma pigmentosum, a rare genetic disorder. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
The only immunoglobulin found as a dimer has what primary function?
A) Protect against invasive helminth infection
B) Protect against viral infections
C) Provide an initial humoral immune response to newly presenting bacterial antigens
D) Inhibiting bacterial adherance and colonization of mucous membranes
E) Provides the most specific recognition to circulating antigens in the bloodstream
answer:
Reformatted Question: The only immunoglobulin found as a <fact1>dimer</fact1> has what primary function?

A) Protect against invasive helminth infection
B) Protect against viral infections
C) Provide an initial humoral immune response to newly presenting bacterial antigens
D) Inhibiting bacterial adherance and colonization of mucous membranes
E) Provides the most specific recognition to circulating antigens in the bloodstream

Answer: D) Inhibiting bacterial adherance and colonization of mucous membranes

question:
A 40-year old man presents to the clinic with vague upper abdominal pain that has been worsening for the last several days. He says that he often gets similar pain but less severe and that it worsens with meals. The pain sometimes radiates to his back. He recently lost 15 kg (33.6 lb) of weight secondary to his lack of appetite since his last visit 2 months ago. He admits to drinking alcohol almost every night since the age of 17. His temperature is 37.0° C (98.6°F), respirations are 15/min, pulse is 67/min, and blood pressure is 122/98 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals moderate epigastric tenderness. An abdominal CT scan reveals calcifications as shown by the white arrows. Which of the following organs is affected in this patient?
A) Pancreas
B) Jejunum
C) Duodenum
D) Large intestine
E) Gall bladder
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>40-year-old man</fact1> presents to the clinic with <fact2>vague upper abdominal pain</fact2> that has been worsening for the last several days. He says that he often gets similar pain but less severe and that it <fact3>worsens with meals</fact3>. The pain sometimes <fact4>radiates to his back</fact4>. He recently lost <fact5>15 kg (33.6 lb) of weight</fact5> secondary to his lack of appetite since his last visit 2 months ago. He admits to <fact6>drinking alcohol almost every night since the age of 17</fact6>. His temperature is <fact7>37.0° C (98.6°F)</fact7>, respirations are <fact8>15/min</fact8>, pulse is <fact9>67/min</fact9>, and blood pressure is <fact10>122/98 mm Hg</fact10>. Physical examination reveals <fact11>moderate epigastric tenderness</fact11>. An abdominal CT scan reveals <fact12>calcifications</fact12> as shown by the white arrows. Which of the following organs is affected in this patient?

Answer: Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>40-year-old man</fact1> presents with <fact2>vague upper abdominal pain</fact2> that <fact3>worsens with meals</fact3> and <fact4>radiates to his back</fact4>, indicating a possible pancreatic issue. His significant weight loss of <fact5>15 kg (33.6 lb)</fact5> and long history of <fact6>drinking alcohol almost every night since the age of 17</fact6> further support this possibility, as chronic alcohol consumption is a common cause of pancreatic disease. Additionally, the physical examination finding of <fact11>moderate epigastric tenderness</fact11> and the abdominal CT scan showing <fact12>calcifications</fact12> are consistent with chronic pancreatitis. Therefore, the organ affected in this patient is the {A} Pancreas.

question:
A 3-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of somnolence, poor feeding, and one episode of vomiting. He is exclusively breastfed. His serum glucose concentration is 88 mg/dL and his serum ammonia concentration is 850 μmol/L (N<90). Urinalysis shows an increased orotic acid to creatinine ratio. Urinary ketones are absent. This patient is most likely deficient in an enzyme that catalyzes which of the following reactions?
A) Ornithine and carbamoyl phosphate to citrulline
B) Orotic acid to uridine monophosphate
C) Pyruvate to acetyl-coenzyme A
D) Glutamate and acetyl-coenzyme A to N-acetylglutamate
E) Arginine to urea and ornithine
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>3-day-old boy</fact1> is brought to the emergency department because of a <fact2>4-hour history of somnolence, poor feeding, and one episode of vomiting</fact2>. He is <fact3>exclusively breastfed</fact3>. His <fact4>serum glucose concentration is 88 mg/dL</fact4> and his <fact5>serum ammonia concentration is 850 μmol/L (N<90)</fact5>. <fact6>Urinalysis shows an increased orotic acid to creatinine ratio</fact6>. <fact7>Urinary ketones are absent</fact7>. This patient is most likely deficient in an enzyme that catalyzes which of the following reactions?

A) Ornithine and carbamoyl phosphate to citrulline
B) Orotic acid to uridine monophosphate
C) Pyruvate to acetyl-coenzyme A
D) Glutamate and acetyl-coenzyme A to N-acetylglutamate
E) Arginine to urea and ornithine

Answer: Analyzing the information provided, the <fact1>3-day-old boy</fact1> presents with symptoms of <fact2>somnolence, poor feeding, and vomiting</fact2>, which are indicative of a severe metabolic disorder. His <fact5>serum ammonia concentration is significantly elevated</fact5>, suggesting a urea cycle disorder. The <fact6>increased orotic acid to creatinine ratio</fact6> in the urinalysis is particularly telling, as orotic acid is a byproduct of pyrimidine synthesis. In the context of a urea cycle disorder, this suggests an issue with the conversion of carbamoyl phosphate to citrulline, which would normally be utilized in the urea cycle. However, the specific reaction that is most directly implicated by the increased orotic acid is the conversion of orotic acid to uridine monophosphate, which is catalyzed by the enzyme orotate phosphoribosyltransferase (OPRT) and/or orotidine 5'-phosphate decarboxylase (ODC), collectively known as the orotate pathway. However, given the options provided, the closest match is the conversion of orotic acid to uridine monophosphate. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 27-year-old gentleman is brought into the ED after being stabbed in the back by a knife. In addition to the pain from the wound, he complains of weakness in his left leg. Upon physical examination you find that he has no other visible injuries; however, he has 2/5 strength in the left lower extremity. Complete neurologic exam also finds a deficit in vibration sense and light touch on the left lower extremity as well as a loss of pain and temperature sensation in the right lower extremity. Which of the following lesions would result in the syndrome described?
A) Anterior cord lesion
B) Posterior cord lesion
C) Right cord hemisection
D) Left cord hemisection
E) Complete cord transection
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>27-year-old gentleman</fact1> is brought into the ED after being <fact2>stabbed in the back by a knife</fact2>. In addition to the <fact3>pain from the wound</fact3>, he complains of <fact4>weakness in his left leg</fact4>. Upon physical examination you find that he has no other visible injuries; however, he has <fact5>2/5 strength in the left lower extremity</fact5>. Complete neurologic exam also finds a <fact6>deficit in vibration sense and light touch on the left lower extremity</fact6> as well as a <fact7>loss of pain and temperature sensation in the right lower extremity</fact7>. Which of the following lesions would result in the syndrome described?

Answer: 
The patient's presentation of <fact4>weakness in his left leg</fact4> with <fact5>2/5 strength in the left lower extremity</fact5> and a <fact6>deficit in vibration sense and light touch on the left lower extremity</fact6> indicates damage to the motor and sensory pathways on the left side of the spinal cord. Additionally, the <fact7>loss of pain and temperature sensation in the right lower extremity</fact7> suggests damage to the spinothalamic tract, which crosses over at the level of entry, affecting the opposite side of the body. This pattern of deficits is consistent with a <fact8>hemisection of the spinal cord</fact8>, specifically affecting the left side of the cord, which would result in ipsilateral motor and sensory deficits and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
A 29-year-old woman presents to the physician with a blurred vision of her right eye for 2 days. She has pain around her right eye during eye movement. She takes no medications. At the clinic, her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, the pulse is 72/min, respirations are 15/min, and the temperature is 36.5℃ (97.7℉). On physical examination, illumination of the left eye results in bilateral pupillary constriction while illumination of the right eye results in a mild bilateral pupillary dilation. Fundoscopic examination shows optic disk swelling in the right eye. The color vision test shows decreased perception in the right eye. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Specific additional history should be obtained regarding which of the following?
A) Dry eyes
B) High-risk sexual behaviour
C) Oral ulcers
D) Sensory loss
E) Late preterm birth
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>29-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the physician with <fact2>blurred vision of her right eye for 2 days</fact2>. She has <fact3>pain around her right eye during eye movement</fact3>. She takes no medications. At the clinic, her <fact4>blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg</fact4>, the <fact5>pulse is 72/min</fact5>, <fact6>respirations are 15/min</fact6>, and the <fact7>temperature is 36.5℃ (97.7℉)</fact7>. On physical examination, <fact8>illumination of the left eye results in bilateral pupillary constriction while illumination of the right eye results in a mild bilateral pupillary dilation</fact8>. <fact9>Fundoscopic examination shows optic disk swelling in the right eye</fact9>. The <fact10>color vision test shows decreased perception in the right eye</fact10>. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Specific additional history should be obtained regarding which of the following?
A) Dry eyes
B) High-risk sexual behaviour
C) Oral ulcers
D) Sensory loss
E) Late preterm birth

Answer: 
Given the patient's symptoms of <fact2>blurred vision of her right eye for 2 days</fact2> and <fact3>pain around her right eye during eye movement</fact3>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact8>abnormal pupillary response</fact8>, <fact9>optic disk swelling in the right eye</fact9>, and <fact10>decreased color vision perception in the right eye</fact10>, these are indicative of optic neuritis. Optic neuritis is often associated with multiple sclerosis (MS), a demyelinating disease that can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms, including sensory loss. Therefore, obtaining a history regarding sensory loss would be relevant to assess for potential MS. The answer is {D}.

question:
An otherwise healthy 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of increasingly frequent episodes of upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. He has had a 3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss during this time. Physical examination shows bilateral pitting pedal edema. An endoscopy shows prominent rugae in the gastric fundus. Biopsy shows parietal cell atrophy. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?
A) Serotonin-secreting gastric tumor
B) Proliferation of gastric mucus-producing cells
C) Neoplasia of submucosal lymphoid tissue
D) Excessive somatostatin secretion
E) Ectopic secretion of gastrin
answer:
Reformatted Question: 

A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a <fact1>6-month history of increasingly frequent episodes of upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea</fact1>. He has had a <fact2>3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss</fact2> during this time. Physical examination shows <fact3>bilateral pitting pedal edema</fact3>. An endoscopy shows <fact4>prominent rugae in the gastric fundus</fact4>. Biopsy shows <fact5>parietal cell atrophy</fact5>. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?

A) Serotonin-secreting gastric tumor
B) Proliferation of gastric mucus-producing cells
C) Neoplasia of submucosal lymphoid tissue
D) Excessive somatostatin secretion
E) Ectopic secretion of gastrin

Answer: 

Analyzing the situation, the patient's <fact1>6-month history of increasingly frequent episodes of upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea</fact1> along with a <fact2>3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss</fact2> suggests a chronic condition affecting the gastrointestinal system. The presence of <fact3>bilateral pitting pedal edema</fact3> may indicate malabsorption or malnutrition. The endoscopy finding of <fact4>prominent rugae in the gastric fundus</fact4> and biopsy result of <fact5>parietal cell atrophy</fact5> are crucial for the diagnosis. Parietal cell atrophy is often associated with autoimmune gastritis or pernicious anemia, which can lead to decreased intrinsic factor production and subsequent vitamin B12 deficiency. However, among the provided options, none directly relate to autoimmune gastritis or pernicious anemia. Considering the options, excessive somatostatin secretion (choice D) can lead to reduced secretion of gastric acid and intrinsic factor, potentially causing similar symptoms and findings. Therefore, the best answer is {D}.

question:
A previously healthy 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation because of loss of appetite, sleeplessness, and extreme irritability for the past 3 weeks. He was recently kicked off of the school's football team after missing too many practices. He has also been avoiding his family and friends because he is not in the mood to see them, but he admits that he is lonely. He has not left his room for 2 days, which prompted his father to bring him to the physician. He has no medical conditions and does not take any medications. He does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. While the father is in the waiting room, a mental status examination is conducted, which shows a constricted affect. Cognition is intact. He says that he would be better off dead and refuses to be treated. He says he wants to use his father's licensed firearm to “end his misery” over the weekend when his parents are at church. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Agree to his wish for no further treatment
B) Begin paroxetine therapy
C) Involuntary hospitalization after informing the parents
D) Reassure the patient that he will feel better
E) Start outpatient psychotherapy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A previously healthy <fact1>14-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the physician for evaluation because of <fact2>loss of appetite, sleeplessness, and extreme irritability</fact2> for the past <fact3>3 weeks</fact3>. He was recently <fact4>kicked off of the school's football team</fact4> after missing too many practices. He has also been <fact5>avoiding his family and friends</fact5> because he is not in the mood to see them, but he admits that he is lonely. He has not left his room for <fact6>2 days</fact6>, which prompted his father to bring him to the physician. He has no medical conditions and does not take any medications. He does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. While the father is in the waiting room, a mental status examination is conducted, which shows a <fact7>constricted affect</fact7>. Cognition is intact. He says that he would be better off dead and refuses to be treated. He says he wants to use his father's licensed firearm to “end his misery” over the weekend when his parents are at church. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>14-year-old boy's</fact1> presentation of <fact2>loss of appetite, sleeplessness, and extreme irritability</fact2> for the past <fact3>3 weeks</fact3>, along with his recent life stressor of being <fact4>kicked off of the school's football team</fact4>, and his <fact5>avoidance of family and friends</fact5>, it is clear that he is experiencing a significant depressive episode. His statement about being "better off dead" and his desire to use a firearm to end his life indicates a high risk of suicide. Given these factors, the most appropriate next step in management is to ensure the patient's safety through <fact8>involuntary hospitalization</fact8> after informing the parents. This will provide a secure environment for further evaluation and treatment. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 48-year-old Caucasian female presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of progressive weakness and shortness of breath. She has had progressive shortness of breath over the last year with an intermittent non-productive cough. In addition, she complains of difficulty raising her arms to brush her hair. Her temperature is 99.6°F (37.6°C), pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Neurologic exam shows 4/5 strength in the deltoid muscles bilaterally. Diffuse dry crackles are heard on lung auscultation. A faint erythematous rash is noted on the malar cheeks, periorbital areas, lateral proximal thighs, and the elbows. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
A) Muscle biopsy
B) CT scan
C) Pulmonary function tests
D) Serum ANA titer
E) Skin biopsy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>48-year-old Caucasian female</fact1> presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of <fact2>progressive weakness and shortness of breath</fact2>. She has had <fact3>progressive shortness of breath over the last year with an intermittent non-productive cough</fact3>. In addition, she complains of <fact4>difficulty raising her arms to brush her hair</fact4>. Her <fact5>temperature is 99.6°F (37.6°C)</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 80/min</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>respirations are 18/min</fact8>, and <fact9>oxygen saturation is 95% on room air</fact9>. Neurologic exam shows <fact10>4/5 strength in the deltoid muscles bilaterally</fact10>. <fact11>Diffuse dry crackles are heard on lung auscultation</fact11>. A <fact12>faint erythematous rash is noted on the malar cheeks, periorbital areas, lateral proximal thighs, and the elbows</fact12>. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
A) Muscle biopsy
B) CT scan
C) Pulmonary function tests
D) Serum ANA titer
E) Skin biopsy

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, including <fact2>progressive weakness and shortness of breath</fact2>, <fact3>progressive shortness of breath over the last year with an intermittent non-productive cough</fact3>, and <fact4>difficulty raising her arms to brush her hair</fact4>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact10>4/5 strength in the deltoid muscles bilaterally</fact10> and <fact11>diffuse dry crackles are heard on lung auscultation</fact11>, and the presence of a <fact12>faint erythematous rash is noted on the malar cheeks, periorbital areas, lateral proximal thighs, and the elbows</fact12>, the clinical picture is suggestive of an autoimmune disorder, specifically Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). The <fact12>faint erythematous rash</fact12> is characteristic of a malar rash, which is a classic symptom of SLE. Among the options provided, the <fact13>serum ANA titer</fact13> is a key test for diagnosing SLE, as a high titer of antinuclear antibodies (ANA) is a common finding in this condition. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 63-year-old man is aiming to improve his health by eating a well balanced diet, walking daily, and quitting smoking following a 45-year smoking history. While on his daily walks he notices a strong cramping pain in his calves that consistently appears after a mile of walking. He sees his physician and a diagnosis of peripheral artery disease with intermittent claudication is made. To improve his symptoms, cilostazol is prescribed. What is the mechanism of action of this medication?
A) Irreversible cyclooxygenase inhibitor
B) Glycoprotein IIB/IIIA inhibitor
C) Thromboxane synthase inhibitor
D) Adenosine diphosphate receptor inhibitor
E) Phosphodiesterase inhibitor
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>63-year-old man</fact1> is aiming to improve his health by eating a well balanced diet, walking daily, and quitting smoking following a <fact2>45-year smoking history</fact2>. While on his daily walks he notices a strong <fact3>cramping pain in his calves</fact3> that consistently appears after a mile of walking. He sees his physician and a diagnosis of <fact4>peripheral artery disease with intermittent claudication</fact4> is made. To improve his symptoms, <fact5>cilostazol</fact5> is prescribed. What is the mechanism of action of this medication?

Answer: The mechanism of action of <fact5>cilostazol</fact5> is as a phosphodiesterase inhibitor. This is relevant to the patient's condition of <fact4>peripheral artery disease with intermittent claudication</fact4> because phosphodiesterase inhibitors can help to dilate blood vessels and improve blood flow, thereby reducing the <fact3>cramping pain in his calves</fact3> that the <fact1>63-year-old man</fact1> experiences during his daily walks.

question:
A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fever, generalized fatigue, and chills for 1 week. She has been having dull right-side abdominal pain during this period. She has nausea. She has no history of travel outside the United States. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and an oral contraceptive. She appears ill. Her temperature is 40°C (104°F), pulse is 118/min, and blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg. On examination, the liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin and is tender. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 14.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 17,100/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 74%
Eosinophils 1%
Lymphocytes 20%
Monocytes 5%
Serum
Glucose 79 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
Total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 180 U/L
AST 69 U/L
ALT 100 U/L
A right upper quadrant ultrasound is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?"
A) Discontinue the oral contraceptive
B) Obtain hepatoiminodiacetic acid scan
C) Perform endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
D) Administer metronidazole
E) Perform percutaneous drainage
"
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>39-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>fever, generalized fatigue, and chills for 1 week</fact2>. She has been having <fact3>dull right-side abdominal pain</fact3> during this period. She has <fact4>nausea</fact4>. She has no history of <fact5>travel outside the United States</fact5>. She has <fact6>type 1 diabetes mellitus</fact6>. Current medications include <fact7>insulin</fact7> and an <fact8>oral contraceptive</fact8>. She appears ill. Her <fact9>temperature is 40°C (104°F)</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 118/min</fact10>, and <fact11>blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg</fact11>. On examination, the <fact12>liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin and is tender</fact12> and there are <fact13>decreased breath sounds over the right lung base</fact13>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
<fact14>Hemoglobin 14.1 g/dL</fact14>
<fact15>Leukocyte count 17,100/mm3</fact15>
<fact16>Segmented neutrophils 74%</fact16>
<fact17>Eosinophils 1%</fact17>
<fact18>Lymphocytes 20%</fact18>
<fact19>Monocytes 5%</fact19>
<fact20>Serum glucose 79 mg/dL</fact20>
<fact21>Serum creatinine 1.1 mg/dL</fact21>
<fact22>Total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL</fact22>
<fact23>Alkaline phosphatase 180 U/L</fact23>
<fact24>AST 69 U/L</fact24>
<fact25>ALT 100 U/L</fact25>
A <fact26>right upper quadrant ultrasound</fact26> is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
